column1:
1,"1","Primary and Secondary Education","

Indonesia divides basic education into two levels: primary school (six years) and junior secondary school (three years). This sub-sector also now includes non-formal education (out-of-school equivalency programs) through Package A (primary) and Package B (junior secondary). The two levels provided formal education by a combination of public and private schools under MoEC, and Islamic schools (Madrasah Ibtidaiyah/MI &
column2: Madrasah Tsanawiyah/MTs), under the responsibility of Ministry of Religious Affairs.

column1: Government Regulation 47/2008 states that the government shall implement a compulsory free education policy, including primary and junior secondary education as well as non-formal education programs (Packages A&
column2: B). The government has implemented several programs to increase the availability and affordability of education services, which function to establish new school units, rehabilitate classrooms, and develop one-roof (satu atap) schools. They also provide
column4: id=27"" target=""_blank"">school operational assistance (BOS), scholarships
column5: for poor students, and other forms of support.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388933"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388933"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Basic Education

column4: id=27"" target=""_blank"">school operational fund assistance (BOS). In 2005, the BOS scheme was introduced and it had the largest impact at school level across the country. The plan of BOS funds for school operational costs is the most significant policy initiative, which is valuable for schools in poorer, more remote areas that often lack of any operational budget.
column5: However, BOS has decreased community participation in education because of parents&rsquo
column6: perception that BOS covers all costs. &nbsp
column7: Also, parents are still asked to make other financial contributions for infrastructure, equipment, and extracurricular expenses.

column1: Another issue has to do with MoEC and MoRA&rsquo
column2: s strategic plan to combine primary and junior secondary school (one-roof). Despite the fact that this has been an important strategy for increasing equitable access, particularly in remote areas, it does not guarantee learning quality as teachers in many on-roof schools are primary school teachers. Since the refurbishment process has been self-managed by the schools, this program has helped to enhance school-based management, with the involvement of school committees and parents. By doing so, it has made a significant contribution to improving learning environments.

column1: Issues also include access and enrollments. The leveling off of both net enrollment rate (NER)
column2: and gross enrollment rate (GER) is presumably due to the difficulty in providing access for all children, particularly those in <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column4: id=3"" target=""_blank"">remote areas. There is also issue with transition rates, in which large numbers of children still do not continue their studies beyond primary level. Children drop out and they tend to come from families with lower socioeconomic status, 64.4% of children aged 7-12 years and 50% of aged 13-15 years. Another issue is teacher qualification and distribution, where teachers tend to prefer to be posted in urban rather than rural areas. To address this issue, the central government has decided to distribute teachers across provinces
column5: provincial governments may distribute teachers across districts
column6: and district governments may distribute teachers within their area. In reality, this decision is administratively difficult to implement etc. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388931"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388931"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Senior Secondary Education

column1: There are several senior secondary education (SSE) type of forms in Indonesia, such a formal, non-formal, and informal. Formal SSE is offered through of general senior secondary schools (SMA),
column3: id=8"" target=""_blank"">vocational senior secondary schools (SMK), and
column4: link=topic&amp
column5: id=6"" target=""_blank"">Islamic senior secondary schools (Madrasah Aliyah/MA). Non-formal SSE consist of senior secondary Package C (Paket C), which is equivalent to SMA. This section concentrates mostly on SMA and MA, though reference is made to SMK in regard to gender equity.

column1: SSE has expanded through private senior secondary schools that continued to dominate the sub-sector in terms of numbers of schools. For approximately 70% of senior secondary schools, privately run schools tend to have much lower enrollments than public schools.
The issues include, but are not limited to, public vs. private senior secondary education where public school system appears to be more efficient than the private school system
column3: the regional divide may not be applicable in the case of SSE enrollments
column4: gender inequality-- the ratio of females to males has actually declined over the past decade, which may be related to the fact that many of the courses offered in SMK are regarded to relate to male-dominated occupations and that SMA courses are seen as more appropriate for females
column6: and inefficiency in senior secondary education in respect to dropout and repetition rates and to a low student/teacher ratio. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388929"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388929"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Skills Development Education

column1: After the government has considered this sub-sector a key strategy for economic development, enrollment in vocational education and training in Indonesia increased 158% between 2001 and 2010. However, this significant growth has tended to be supply-driven rather than demand-driven, which has created obstacles in ensuring that the skills of the graduates from vocational education and training are matched to the demands of the labor market. Vocational education and training is offered through both formal and non-formal services. Formal vocational education is the larger of the two sub-sectors and is offered at secondary levels through vocational senior secondary schools (SMK) and higher education levels through Diploma I, II, III, and IV programs including a 3-year program within polytechnics and academies (akademi) by both public and private institutions.

Under all education-related laws, vocational education at the senior secondary and tertiary levels is mandated. Operationalized under the National Education Standards Board (BSNP), the National Standards of Education (SNP) set the standards for vocational education. The Directorate General (DG) of Senior Secondary Education (SSE) has the main responsibility for overseeing formal vocational education at the SSE
column2: level. The responsibility for vocational education at the tertiary level sits with the DG of Higher Education. Non-formal vocational training is the responsibility of the DG of Early Childhood Education, Non-formal Education, and Informal Education, which are within the Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC). The new system introduced by Ministry of Education Decree 036/O/1997 has only one type of vocational secondary school (Sekolah Menengah Kejuruan or SMK) from previously six types. Within this system, an SMK may provide a wide range of vocational subjects rather than specializing in only a limited number of fields.

column1: Some issues are: supply and demand--education should be conducted through a demand-based approach, as the supply-based vocational education fails to equip students with skills that fit industry demands. To assist with better planning and service provision, a routine demand analysis on human resource should be conducted to better serve the labor market
column3: the only significant difference in terms of gender and enrollment within the senior secondary education sub-sector is the level of female enrollment in vocational secondary schools
column4: dropout rates--dropout rates fluctuated over the past decade. The higher dropout rate from SMK may be associated with socio-economic status as students tend to come from families with a lower economic status than their SMA counterparts, etc. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388927"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388927"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: International Standard Schools
set international standard education units in order to prepare capable students to compete on an international playing field. Law 20/2003&rsquo
column4: international standard units as strategy for improving quality. The International Standard Schools (ISS) law has been in debate these past few years and is currently under review by the Constitutional Court.

column1: ISS qualification is that the school must meet the eight National Education Standards (NES). The ISS general characteristics or requirements that are identified by Ministerial Regulation 78/2009 are: (i) using English as the medium of instruction in science, mathematics, and vocational subjects
column2: (ii) adopting curricula and an accreditation standard from an OECD or other developed country
column3: (iii) being accredited by a school in an OECD or other developed country
column4: engaging and collaborating with an overseas &ldquo
column6: (iv) requiring teachers and principals to have S2 (masters) degrees (v) having fully equipped ICT facilities

column1: Some issues include the fact that International School Stubs (RSBI) special training on management, administration, and monitoring and evaluation have not been received by the provincial and city/district staff who handle RSBI responsibilities. The ISS program debate is also focused on the issues of equity, access, and school capacity, as well as whether the policy is based on the basic principles of quality and equitable access that guide education in Indonesia. The current RSBI program is also seen as not affordable and none of the RSBIs have achieved ISS status. Very few, in fact, are meeting standards. Requirement to teach English becomes a barrier for teachers and students to understand the material.
Some proposed options include maintaining current ISS policy
column2: terminating the RSBI program, as it has also been criticized that it discriminates against disadvantaged children and children from lower socioeconomic strata although termination of the program could have a negative impact in community coherence and education quality improvement motivation in the future, etc. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column4: id=24"" target=""_blank"">Read more

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388924"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388924"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Gender Mainstreaming

column1: Indonesia has been improving the gender equity in education since the last decade, by taking further steps to provide equal access for both genders. The country commits
column2: to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of including
column3: gender equity in both primary and secondary education, as well as in early childhood, technical and vocational, and higher education. Gender parity at all levels of the education system and literacy rates for Indonesia&rsquo
column4: s youth (15-24 age group) have been greatly achieved. These achievements came from a combination of effective policies and national investments in education that have expanded school availability in <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column6: id=3"" target=""_blank"">rural areas the lowered the school costs.

column1: Some issues include, but are not limited to, lack of a clear strategic direction for gender mainstreaming in education
column3: the needs of improvement of the government staff sensitivity in this area, because many pioneers in this field have retired and gender equality skills and knowledge have not been regenerated
column4: the failure to notice in training teachers to treat females and males equally through sharing tasks&nbsp
column5: and participation in the classroom, etc.

column1: The proposed options are the need for gender expertise in the government staff to implement and maintain gender equality in education
column2: train male and female team members to ensure all activities throughout the education system are gender sensitive
column3: teachers are to encourage boys and girls to undertake certain activities, provide a sense of direction and acting as role model themselves as well as to give equal attention for them
column4: have a comprehensive pre-service teacher training programmer and in-service school supervisor, principal, and teacher training programmes to focus on skills for improved gender responsive
column5: and review the curricula to ensure there is no gender bias or gender stereotyping. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388920"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388920"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Student Health and Nutrition

column1: The Supplemental Food for School Children Program (PMT-AS) was launched to contribute to acceleration of achievement of national development goals related to overcoming malnutrition (the incidence of stunting in children aged 6-14 years was 13.3 percent for boys and 10.9 percent for girls in 2010) achieving education for all, and poverty reduction. The PMT-AS Program was formulated to: (1) improve nutritional intake
column3: (3) increase the attendance and learning interest
column4: (4) increase preference for local nutritious food
column5: (5) improve hygiene and healthy behaviors including healthy eating habits
column8: s income through the increased use of local products. During 2010 and 2011, the program was implemented by the Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC) and the Ministry of Religious Affairs (MoRA). In 2010 the target was limited to regular and madrasah primary schoolchildren (SD/MI) grades 1-6, and in 2011 preschoolers (TK/RA) were added to the program.

column1: ACDP conducted a study to evaluate the program and found, among others, overall good performance in meeting teacher-student ratios and numbers of teachers per school, average performance in class size and teacher education, and very poor performance for teacher and principal certification. Because
column3: id=7"" target=""_blank"">teachers and principals have important roles in managing the PMT-AS Program, their lack of education and/or certification may have impacted negatively on program implementation. Furthermore, 20% of children in the sample districts had less than three meals per day and 20 percent go without breakfast. More than half the sample schools (65% on average) rely on well water while less than 10 percent of the sample schools (8.7% on average) rely on river water. However, the quality of the water and the quantity of water availability throughout the year are unknown. The availability of sanitation facilities in the sample schools is less than satisfactory.
column4: link=topic&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390388917"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390388917"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Education Financing

column3: MoRA) funding passage makes basic education financing here rather complicated. Basic education is mostly provided by the national education budget. 66% from MoEC, 28% MoRA, and the remaining 6% distributed to other ministries providing training and education. 60% of the national budget is transferred to sub-national governments by MoEC, while MoRA manages its fund allocation straight to schools. Another significant allocation is the school operational assistance grant (BOS), which is allocated to schools via the provincial offices. The BOS programme aimed to help the financial burden on families of sending their kids to school. Unfortunately, among its issues is the fact that although the grant is meant for development costs of a child, schools tend to use it to manage operational issues.

column2: s database have been made by giving unique numbers to individual students and identifiers for schools with their GPS coordinates to make an effective system for expenditure tracking. However, there are some issues with the efficient use of resources, such as the difficulty to know how money is being spent and identify where it goes. Planning and budget are more focused on the needs of the organizational units within the bureaucracy than the schools themselves
column4: per-student formula does not take into account the differences in operating costs schools face due to the circumstances of, among others, their populations and locations.

column1: There are also some issues in equity, such as the fact that funding for private madrasah is unequal compared to funding for state schools, including state madrasah. Also, to enable greater allocative and technical efficiencies, the education financing still needs to be integrated and simplified. Equity concerns are being addressed by BOS and to a lesser extent the BSM.

Ensuring Gender Equity in Education. Jakarta: ACDP.

column1:
,Pendidikan Dasar dan Menengah","

Indonesia membagi pendidikan dasar menjadi dua tingkatan: sekolah dasar (enam tahun) dan sekolah menengah pertama (tiga tahun). SUb-sektor ini juga sekarang memasukan pendidikan non-formal (program kesetaraan di luar sekolah) melalui Paket A (SD) dan Paket B (SMP). Dua tingkatan dalam bentuk pendidikan formal ini disediakan di sekolah negeri dan swasta di bawah Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan, dan sekolah-sekolah Islam (Madrasah Ibtidaiyah / MI &
column2: Madrasah Tsanawiyah / MTs), di bawah kewenangan Kementerian Agama.

column1: Peraturan nomor 47/2008 menyatakan bahwa pemerintah harus melaksanakan kebijakan wajib belajar gratis, meliputi pendidikan dasar dan menengah serta program pendidikan non-formal (Paket A &
column2: B). Pemerintah telah menerapkan beberapa program untuk meningkatkan ketersediaan dan keterjangkauan layanan pendidikan, yang berfungsi untuk membangun unit sekolah baru, merehabilitasi ruang kelas, dan mengembangkan sekolah satu atap. Mereka juga memberikan bantuan operasional sekolah (BOS), beasiswa&nbsp
column4: dan bentuk-bentuk bantuan lainnya.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389013"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389013"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pendidikan Dasar

column1: Pada tahun 2005, skema BOS diperkenalkan dan memberikan pengaruh besar sekolah di seluruh negeri. Rencana dana BOS untuk biaya operasional sekolah merupakan inisiatif kebijakan yang paling signifikan, yang berharga bagi sekolah-sekolah di
column2: daerah miskin dan terpencil yang sering mengalami kekurangan dalam setiap anggaran operasional. Namun, BOS menurunkan partisipasi masyarakat dalam pendidikan karena orang tua berpendapat bahwa BOS sudah mencakup semua biaya. Disamping itu, orang tua masih diminta untuk memberikan kontribusi keuangan lainnya untuk infrastruktur, peralatan, dan biaya ekstrakurikuler.

column1: Komponen utama rencana strategis Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan dan Kementerian Agama adalah untuk menggabungkan sekolah SD dan SMP (satu atap). Terlepas dari pentingnya strategi untuk meningkatkan akses yang merata, terutama di daerah terpencil, namun tidak ada jaminan adanya pembelajaran berkualitas karena banyak guru di sekolah satu atap adalah guru sekolah dasar. Karena proses perbaikan dikelola sendiri oleh sekolah, program ini membantu peningkatan sekolah berbasis manajemen, dengan melibatkan komite sekolah dan orang tua. Dengan demikian, kontribusi yang signifikan untuk meningkatkan lingkungan belajar juga bisa diberikan.

Beberapa masalah diantaranya ialah akses dan pendaftaran. Penyamaan APM dan APK diduga karena kesulitan dalam menyediakan akses bagi semua anak, terutama di daerah terpencil. Selain itu ada juga maslah dengan tingkat transisi, di mana sejumlah besar anak-anak masih tidak melanjutkan studi mereka setelah tingkat dasar. Anak-anak putus sekolah cenderung berasal dari keluarga dengan status sosial ekonomi rendah, masing-masing sebesar 64,4% anak usia 7-12 tahun dan 50% anak usia 13-15 tahun. Masalah lainnya adalah kualifikasi dan penyebaran guru, di mana guru cenderung lebih suka untuk ditempatkan di perkotaan daripada di pedesaan. Untuk mengatasi masalah ini, pemerintah pusat membuat keputusan untuk mendistribusikan guru di seluruh provinsi
column2: pemerintah provinsi dapat mendistribusikan guru di seluruh kabupaten
column3: dan pemerintah kabupaten dapat mendistribusikan guru di daerah mereka. Pada kenyataannya, keputusan ini secara administratif sulit untuk diterapkan,&nbsp
column4: dll. Baca lebih lanjut

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389011"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389011"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pendidikan Menengah

column1: Ada beberapa jenis pendidikan menengah atas (SMA) di Indonesia, seperti formal, non-formal, dan informal. Pendidikan menengah atas
column2: diberikan melalui sekolah umum menengah atas (SMA), sekolah menengah atas kejuruan (SMK), dan Madrasah Aliyah / MA. Pendidikan menengah atas &nbsp
column3: non formal terdiri dari Paket pendidikan menengah atas &nbsp
column4: (Paket C), yang setara dengan SMA. Paket inilebih banyak berkonsentrasi pada SMA dan MA, meskipun pedoman untuk SMK sudah dibuat&nbsp

column1: Pendidikan menengah atas telah diperluas oleh sekolah menengah swasta yang dalam hal jumlah sekolah terus mendominasi sub-sektor ini. Sekitar 70% dari sekolah menengah atas, sekolah yang dikelola swasta cenderung memiliki pendaftaran yang jauh lebih rendah dari sekolah umum.
Permasalahan yang muncul diantaranya ialah pendidikan menengah atas negeri tampaknya lebih efisien daripada sistem sekolah swasta
column2: ketidaksetaraan geografis - kesenjangan daerah mungkin tidak berpengaruh pada pendaftaran pendidikan menegah atas ini
column3: ketidaksetaraan gender - rasio perempuan dan laki-laki menurun selama dekade terakhir, mungkin karena banyak program studi yang ditawarkan di SMK dianggap berhubungan dengan pekerjaan laki-laki dan pendidikan di SMA dipandang lebih sesuai untuk perempuan
column4: dan inefisiensi dalam pendidikan menengah terkait tingkat putus sekolah dan pengulangan serta rasio siswa / guru yang rendah. Baca lebih lanjut

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389009"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389009"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pendidikan Kejuruan

column1: Setelah pemerintah memasukan sub-sektor kejuruan sebagai strategi penting dalam pembangunan ekonomi, pendaftaran di pendidikan kejuruan dan pelatihan di Indonesia meningkat 158% antara tahun 2001 dan 2010. Namun, pertumbuhan yang signifikan ini cenderung
column2: menjadikannya supply driven daripada demand-driven, masalahpun muncul karena keterampilan lulusan dari pendidikan dan pelatihan kejuruan harus disesuaikan dengan tuntutan pasar tenaga kerja. Pendidikan dan pelatihan kejuruan diselenggarakan melalui layanan formal dan non-formal. Pendidikan kejuruan formal lebih besar dari dua sub-sektor lain dan diberikan pada tingkat menengah melalui sekolah-sekolah kejuruan menengah atas (SMK) dan tingkat pendidikan tinggi melalui Diploma I, II, III, dan IV termasuk program 3-tahun di politeknik dan akademi &nbsp
column3: yang diselenggarakan baik oleh kedua lembaga pemerintah maupun swasta.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column1: Semua undang-undang yang berhubungan dengan pendidikan mengamanatkan tentang pendidikan kejuruan di tingkat menengah dan tinggi. Dilaksanakan oleh Badan Standar Nasional Pendidikan (BSNP), Standar Nasional Pendidikan (SNP) menetapkan standar untuk pendidikan kejuruan. Direktorat Jenderal (Ditjen) Pendidikan Menengah Atas memiliki tanggung jawab utama untuk mengawasi pendidikan kejuruan formal di tingkat pendidikan menengah atas. Tanggung jawab untuk pendidikan kejuruan di tingkat pendidikan tinggi berada dibawah Ditjen Pendidikan Tinggi. Pelatihan kejuruan non-formal merupakan tanggung jawab Ditjen Pendidikan Anak Usia Dini, Pendidikan Non-formal, dan Pendidikan Informal, yang berada di Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan. Sistem baru yang dikenalkan dalam Keputusan Menteri Pendidikan no. 36 / O / 1997 hanya memiliki satu jenis sekolah menengah kejuruan (SMK) dari enam jenis yang sebelumnya ada. Dalam sistem ini, sebuah SMK dapat memberikan berbagai mata pelajaran kejuruan dan tidak mengkhususkan diri hanya dalam bidang terbatas.
Beberapa masalah diantaranya: ketersediaan dan permintaan - pendidikan harus dilakukan dengan pendekatan berbasis permintaan, karena pendekatan berbasis ketersediaan tidak dapat
column2: membekali siswa dengan keterampilan yang sesuai dengan tuntutan industri. Untuk membuat perencanaan dan pelayanan yang lebih baik, analisis rutin permintaan pada sumber daya manusia harus dilakukan untuk lebih melayani pasar tenaga kerja
column3: perbedaan gender - satu-satunya perbedaan yang signifikan dalam hal gender dan pendaftaran pada sub-sektor pendidikan menengah atas adalah tingkat pendaftaran perempuan di sekolah menengah kejuruan
column4: angka putus sekolah - angka putus sekolah turun naik selama dekade terakhir. Angka putus sekolah yang lebih tinggi dari SMK berhubungan dengan status sosial-ekonomi karena siswa umumnya berasal dari keluarga dengan status ekonomi rendah dibanding dengan rekan-rekan SMA mereka, dll. column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389007"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389007"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Sekolah Berstandar Internasional (SBI)

column1: UU Pendidikan Nasional menetapkan Sekolah Berstandar Internasional untuk menyelenggarakan satuan pendidikan bertaraf internasional dalam rangka mempersiapkan siswa agar mampu bersaing di lapangan internasional. Tujuan UU No. 20/2003 adalah untuk membentuk standar pendidikan yang meliputi satuan bersandar internasional sebagai strategi untuk meningkatkan kualitas. UU mengenai Sekolah Berstandar Internasional
column2: dipertanyakan beberapa tahun terakhir ini dan saat ini sedang ditinjau oleh Mahkamah Konstitusi.

column1: Kualifikasi SBI adalah bahwa sekolah harus memenuhi delapan Standar Nasional Pendidikan (SPN). Karakteristik
column2: dan persyaratan umum SBI menurut Peraturan Menteri 78/2009 adalah: (i) menggunakan bahasa Inggris sebagai pengantar dalam sains, matematika, dan mata pelajaran kejuruan
column3: (ii) mengadopsi kurikulum dan standar akreditasi dari OECD atau negara maju lainnya
column4: (iii) terakreditasi oleh sekolah dari OECD atau negara maju lainnya
column5: terlibat dan berkolaborasi dengan luar negeri sebagai &ldquo

column2: dengan beberapa permasalahan tentang pemerataan, akses &nbsp

Program RSBI saat ini juga dianggap tidak terjangkau dan tidak ada satupun RSBIs telah mencapai status SBI.Pada kenyataaannya,&nbsp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389005"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389005"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pengarusutamaan Gender

column1: Indonesia telah meningkatkan kesetaraan gender dalam pendidikan sejak dekade terakhir dengan mengambil langkah-langkah lebih lanjut untuk memberikan akses yang sama pada kedua gender. Negara ini berkomitmen untuk Millenium Development Goals (MDG) dan Tujuan Pembangunan Berkelanjutan (SDG). MDG dan SDG mamasukan kesetaraan gender dalam pendidikan dasar dan menengah, serta pendidikan anak usia dini, teknis dan kejuruan, dan pendidikan tinggi. Kesetaraan gender di semua tingkat sistem pendidikan dan tingkat literasi untuk pemuda Indonesia
column3: kebijakan yang efektif dan investasi nasional pendidikan telah memperluas ketersediaan sekolah dengan biaya yang kecil di daerah pedesaan.

column2: arah strategis pengarusutamaan gender dalam pendidikan masih kurang jelas
column4: &nbsp
column6: sensitivitas pegawai pemerintah di daerah, karena banyak pelopor dalam bidang ini telah pensiun sementara keahlian dan&nbsp
column7: pengetahuan mengenai kesetaraan gender tidak diregenarasi
column8: belum adanya pelatihan guru yang memperlakukan wanita dan pria sama dalam pembagian tugas dan partisipasi didalam kelas.

column1: Pilihan yang diusulkan adalah kebutuhan agar para pegawai pemerintah memiliki keahlian gender untuk dapat menerapkan dan memelihara kesetaraan gender dalam pendidikan
column2: melatih laki-laki dan anggota tim perempuan untuk memastikan semua kegiatan di seluruh sistem pendidikan sensitif terhadap gender
column3: guru mendorong anak laki-laki dan perempuan melakukan kegiatan, memberikan arah dan bertindak sebagai panutan untuk diri sendiri maupun untuk memberikan perhatian yang sama bagi mereka
column4: memiliki program pelatihan guru pra-jabatan dan dalam jabatan yang komprehensif untuk pengawas, kepala sekolah, dan guru dengan fokus pada keterampilan agar responsif pada gender
column5: dan meninjau kurikulum untuk memastikan tidak ada bias gender atau stereotip gender. Baca lebih lanjut

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389003"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389003"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Kesehatan dan Gizi Siswa

column1: Pemberian Makanan Tambahan Anak Sekolah (PMT - AS) diluncurkan untuk mendorong percepatan pencapaian tujuan pembangunan nasional terkait upaya untuk mengatasi gizi buruk (jumlahnya cukup mengejutkan anak usia 6 - 14 tahun sebesar 13,3 persen untuk anak laki-laki dan 10,9 persen untuk anak perempuan pada tahun 2010) mewujudkan pendidikan untuk semua, dan mengurangi kemiskinan. Program PMT - AS dibuat untuk: (1) meningkatkan asupan gizi
column3: (3) meningkatkan minat untuk hadir dan belajar
column4: (4) menambah preferensi untuk makanan bergizi lokal
column5: (5) meningkatkan kebersihan dan perilaku sehat termasuk kebiasaan makan yang sehat
column7: dan (7) meningkatkan pendapatan masyarakat melalui peningkatan penggunaan produk lokal. Selama tahun 2010 dan 2011, program ini dilaksanakan oleh Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan (Kemendikbud) dan Kementerian Agama (Kemenag). Pada tahun 2010 targetnya &nbsp
column8: terbatas pada sekolah dasar umum dan madrasah (SD / MI) kelas 1 - 6, dan pada tahun 2011 anak-anak prasekolah (TK / RA) juga dimasukan dalam program.

column1: ACDP melakukan penelitian untuk mengevaluasi program dan menemukan, antara lain, adanya kinerja yang baik secara keseluruhan dalam memenuhi rasio siswa guru serta jumlah guru per sekolah guru-murid, kinerja rata-rata berdasarkan ukuran kelas dan pendidikan guru, dan kinerja sertifikasi guru dan kepala sekolah yang sangat buruk. Karena guru dan kepala sekolah memiliki peran penting dalam mengelola Program PMT-AS, rendahnya pendidikan dan / atau sertifikasi dapat berdampak negatif pada pelaksanaan program. Disamping itu, 20 persen anak-anak di kabupaten sampel makan kurang dari tiga kali per hari dan 20 persen pergi sekolah tanpa sarapan. Lebih dari separuh sekolah sampel (65 persen) mengandalkan air sumur sementara kurang dari 10 persen dari sekolah sampel (rata-rata 8,7 persen) bergantung pada air sungai. Namun, kualitas air dan kuantitas ketersediaan air sepanjang tahun tidak diketahui. Ketersediaan fasilitas sanitasi di sekolah sampel kurang dari memuaskan. Baca lebih lanjut

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390389000"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390389000"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pembiayaan Pendidikan

column3: Kementerian Agama) membuat pembiayaan pendidikan dasar menjadi agak rumit. Pendidikan dasar sebagian besar disediakan oleh anggaran pendidikan nasional. 66% dari Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan, 28% dari Kementerian Agama, dan sisanya 6% didistribusikan ke kementerian lain yang memberikan pelatihan dan pendidikan. Sekitar 60% dari anggaran nasional ditransfer ke pemerintah daerah oleh Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan, sedangkan Kemenag mengelola alokasi dana langsung ke sekolah-sekolah. Alokasi signifikan lain adalah Bantuan sekolah operasional / BOS, yang dialokasikan ke sekolah-sekolah melalui kantor provinsi. Program BOS bertujuan untuk membantu beban keuangan keluarga dalam menyekolahkan anak-anaknya. Sayangnya, meskipun hibah tersebut dimaksudkan untuk biaya pengembangan anak, sekolah biasanya menggunakannya untuk mengelola masalah operasional.

column1: Perbaikan basis data dilakukan oleh Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan dengan cara memberikan nomor unik untuk masing-masing siswa dan pengenal untuk sekolah dengan koordinat GPS untuk membuat sistem pelacakan pengeluaran yang efektif. Namun, ada beberapa masalah dalam penggunaan sumber daya yang efisien, misalnya kesulitan untuk mengetahui bagaimana dan kemana uang dibelanjakan. Perencanaan dan anggaran lebih terfokus pada kebutuhan unit-unit organisasi dalam birokrasi daripada sekolah itu sendiri
column2: Formula alokasi BOS dan BOSDA per - siswa tidak &nbsp
column3: memperhitungkan perbedaan biaya operasional sekolah yang disebabkan, antara lain, faktor populasi dan lokasi mereka.

column1: Ada juga beberapa masalah mengenai pemerataan, seperti adanya fakta bahwa dana untuk madrasah swasta tidak setara dibandingkan dengan dana untuk sekolah negeri, termasuk madrasah negeri. Juga, dalam mendorong efisiensi pengalokasian dan teknis, pembiayaan pendidikan masih perlu diintegrasikan dan disederhanakan. Masalah pemerataan diatasi melalui BOS dan pada tingkat lebih rendah dengan BSM. Baca lebih lanjut

2,"1","Early Childhood Education","

International educational research and recent findings in cognitive science have highlighted the importance and advantage of early childhood development (ECD). From the period before a child is born until their eighth birthday, the central nervous system, brain cells and neural pathways are being established. During this critical period of brain development, the foundation for a child&rsquo
column2: s future life trajectory is set. The magnitude of benefits derived from cognitive stimulation provided during the ages of 0-4 has led researchers to call this the &lsquo
column4: of development. In it, cognitive, social and emotional development take&nbsp
column5: place, which will eventually affect the health, learning and behavior throughout a person&rsquo
column6: s life. Cognitive neuroscientists refer to this as the &ldquo
column10: child that does not receive the necessary stimulation to develop the brain during this time&nbsp
column11: will have irreparable damage in school and later life.

column1: At a national conference on ECD held in Jakarta in October 2012, followed by an international conference where specialists from many countries deliberated on the importance of ECD in the post MDG agenda, Indonesia strongly recommended that the global forum give priority to the essential role of the early years in shaping individuals&rsquo
column3: well-being by creating a new development goal specifi cally for ECD. Indonesia supports the notion that all children have the right to develop to their full potential by growing up physically healthy, mentally alert, socially competent, emotionally sound, able to learn, and with the resources to live long and productive lives.

column1: The government has also recognized the importance of Holistic Integrated (HI) ECD and of creating the links between early education and other services to facilitate a HI ECD approach. This is apparent in Indonesia&rsquo
column2: s National Strategy and Presidential Regulation 60/2013, both on HI ECD
column4: to improve implementation and coordination through the establishment of a multi-agency task force.

column1: In recent years, Indonesia has experienced a rapid increase in the number of children participating in playgroups, kindergartens and childcare services, mostly due to the government&rsquo
column2: s active promotion of such services. Participation rates vary considerably by region and wealth. 70% of the richest 20% of households were shown to participate, while only 45% of the poorest 20% of households participated, and there are large regional disparities. Participation is also determined by a mother&rsquo
column3: s education level. A child whose mother has at least completed primary education is 30% more likely to participate in ECD or TK by age 5. According to Puslitjak research, ECD access is also determined by families&rsquo
column4: distance to school and transportation costs.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390393919"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390393919"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Early Childhood Development (ECD)

column1: ECD is provided in formal and non-formal settings. However, much of the early-years provision in Indonesia is provided outside the formal education and health sectors. An ACDP qualitative research exercise on four-sites attempts to distinguish the different types of ECD centers that had evolved in communities, among those that developed out of community efforts and those out of institutional grant and support from the Government of Indonesia, Multilateral Donors, or NGO funding.
Some of the issues in ECD are local delivery&mdash
column2: there is a poor coordination between central and provincial levels persists, making implementation of provision at district and community level problematic and overlapping and sometimes unclear division of responsibilities between central, provincial, and district levels hampers the efficient operations of ECD and HI ECD
column3: ECD financing--public investment may not be targeted well to improve equity, as current financing models tend to favor centers with more capacity for self-financing and public support for training materials and operational support, maternal and child health components of HI ECD are more favorably resourced than ECD, etc.
column4: quality assurance--an ACDP study found that many non-formal ECD institutions have been unable to meet all of the eight standards set out in <a href=""https://www.tusfiles.net/38uwl6smaliq"" target=""_blank"">Minister of Education and Culture&nbsp
column5: decree No. 137/2014, which presents quality control by the Ministry, and another ACDP study showed that for HI ECD teachers, personal skills, commitment and an affinity to children are more important for providing quality teaching at this level than formal qualifications.

column1: The proposed options can be divided to three different levels, National, Provincial/District, and Community.
column2: The national level includes increasing provision and participation in early childhood care and education, and progressively raises its budget expenditure as a proportion of its total outlays
column3: creating a flexible Development Model as a resource for districts and villages to draw upon
column4: etc. &nbsp
column5: The provincial/district level includes the district Offices of Education must support poor and newly established ECD that do not have enough power to raise their own funds and those which accommodate children from poor families
column6: developing a resource bank within each district office to include materials that capture best practice in development, financing and provision of HI ECD
column7: developing and test community-led targeting strategies for local investment in ECD and techniques for self-financing initiatives, etc. &nbsp
column8: The community level includes educating parents on the purpose of ECD and HI ECD and informs them about what constitutes quality ECD
column9: identifying and allocating resources to a local ECD leadership/coordination body
column10: strengthen the outreach of Posyandu, midwives and health facilities based on local assessments, etc. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390393917"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390393917"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Family Education

column1: Parents and other primary caregivers have the most significant influence on a child&rsquo
column2: s physical, cognitive, psychosocial and emotional development. &nbsp
column3: Each child needs at least one primary caregiver whom he or she can trust and is close to in order to have an optimal development. &nbsp
column4: Family education or parenting education aims to improve the child and the family&rsquo
column5: s well-being, which can be found in the studies by Harlen et. Al and the World Bank that show parents&rsquo
column6: active role can improve a child&rsquo
column8: It is also related to Early Childhood Development (ECD), which interventions include educating and supporting parents, developing the capacities of caregivers, and using mass communication to enhance parents and caregivers&rsquo

column1: A number of ministries in Indonesia have provided services to improve child and family well-being in children'
column3: such as Kelas Ibu (Mother Class) by Ministry of Health and programs targeted for poor families by the Ministry of Social Affairs. Although&nbsp
column4: there are challenges, the government has built a solid system of early childhood education&nbsp
column5: services and ECD programs have increased over the last decade.

column1: Education programs need to have the right content, delivery, and design components, to reach better results.
column2: Also, parenting education providers are recommended to choose a specific, meaningful set of key messages and adapt content for particularly vulnerable families. &nbsp
column3: Recommendations to improve program design and implementation include: (i) active learning, (ii) explicit goals, (iii) sufficient duration and intensity, (iv) practice, (v) appropriate content, (vi) responsiveness, (vii) community support, and (viii) trained and competent staff.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390393912"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390393912"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Quality Assurance (QA)

column1: QA refers to a systematic and effective process of checking to see whether a service being developed is meeting specified requirements or standards. In order to improve the capacity of children (from birth to 6 years of age) to develop and learn, ECE services should be of high quality and the providers need to be held accountable for such quality. However, the provision of high-quality ECE services is still a major challenge facing Indonesia. The initial step for the development of a QA system has already been taken in the form of the regulatory framework from the constitution itself to government, presidential and ministerial regulations and the ministry&rsquo
column2: s strategic plan as well as the establishing of national standards for ECE services. The establishment of a Directorate General of Early Childhood Education and Community Education (DGPAUD DIKMAS)
column3: in the restructuring of MoEC is an example of such move. What is critical at this stage is to ensure the effective implementation of these regulations, particularly at the decentralised district and community levels, as well as to establish the processes to assure the quality aligned to such standards is being achieved. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1:
,Pendidikan Anak Usia Dini","

Penelitian pendidikan internasional dan temuan terbaru dalam ilmu kognitif telah menyoroti esensi dan manfaat dari pengembangan anak usia dini (PAUD). Dari periode sebelum anak lahir sampai ulang tahun kedelapan mereka, sistem saraf pusat, sel-sel otak dan jalur saraf sedang dibentuk. Selama masa penting perkembangan otak ini, dasar lintasan anak untuk kehidupan masa depan diatur. Besarnya manfaat yang berasal dari stimulasi kognitif yang diberikan selama usia 0-4 membuat para peneliti menyebutnya sebagai '
column3: perkembangan di mana pengembangan kognitif, sosial dan emosional yang berlangsung akan mempengaruhi kesehatan, belajar dan perilaku kehidupan seseorang. Ahli saraf kognitif menyebutnya sebagai masa &ldquo
column4: use it or lose it&rdquo
column5: . Jika seorang anak tidak menerima rangsangan yang diperlukan untuk pengembangan otaknya saat itu, akan ada kerusakan individu di sekolah dan kehidupannya nanti yang tidak dapat diperbaiki.

column1: Pemerintah menyadari pentingnya Pengembangan Anak Usia Dini Holistik Integratif (PAUD HI) dan menciptakan hubungan antara pendidikan awal dan layanan lainnya untuk memfasilitasi pendekatan PAUD HI. Hal ini terlihat dalam Strategi Nasionadi Indonesia terkait PAUD HI dan dalam peraturan Presiden 20/2013 tentang PAUD HI, yang bertujuan untuk meningkatkan pelaksanaan dan koordinasi melalui pembentukan satuan tugas multi-lembaga.

Dalam beberapa tahun terakhir, jumlah anak yang berpartisipasi dalam kelompok bermain, taman kanak-kanak dan jasa perawatan anak di Indonesia mengalami peningkatan pesat, dan sebagian besar karena promosi aktif pemerintah tentang layanan tersebut. Tingkat partisipasi sangat bervariasi menurut wilayah dan kekayaan. Sekitar 70% dari terkaya 20% keluarga kelihatan berpartisipasi, sementara hanya 45% dari termiskin 20% keluarga kelihatan berpartisipasi, dan ada kesenjangan regional yang besar. Partisipasi juga ditentukan oleh tingkat pendidikan seorang ibu. Seorang anak yang ibunya setidaknya telah menyelesaikan pendidikan dasar adalah 30% lebih mungkin untuk berpartisipasi dalam PAUD atau TK pada usia 5. Menurut penelitian Puslitjak, akses terhadap PAUD juga ditentukan oleh jarak keluarga ke sekolah serta oleh biaya transportasi.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390393938"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390393938"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pengembangan Anak Usia Dini

column1: PAUD diselenggarakan dalam bentuk formal dan non-formal. Namun di Indonesia, penyelenggaraannya lebih banyak dilakukan oleh selain sektor formal pendidikan dan kesehatan. Dalam penelitian kualitatif ACDP pada empat bidang dilakukan untuk membedakan antara berbagai jenis pusat PAUD yang telah berkembang di masyarakat. Penelitian ini membedakan antara pusat yang dikembangkan oleh masyarakat dan pusat yang dikembangkan sebagai hasil dari hibah kelembagaan dan bantuan dari Pemerintah Indonesia, Multilateral Donor atau pendanaan LSM.
Beberapa masalah di PAUD adalah Local delivery &ndash
column2: adanya koordinasi yang buruk antara tingkat pusat dan provinsi membuat pelaksanaan penyelenggaraannya di tingkat daerah dan masyarakat bermasalah dan tumpang tindih serta kadang-kadang ketidakjelasan pembagian tanggung jawab antara pusat, provinsi dan kabupaten provinsi pusat menghambat jalannya penyelenggaraan PAUD dan PAUD HI yang &nbsp
column4: pembiayaan PAUD- investasi pemerintah mungkin tidak tepat sasaran untuk meningkatkan pemerataan, karena model pembiayaan saat ini cenderung mendorong pusat pendidikan ini agar memiliki kapasitas untuk pembiayaan sendiri dan bantuan pemerintah digunakan untuk bahan pelatihan dan operasional, komponen kesehatan ibu dan anak dalam PAUD HI &nbsp
column7: jaminan kualitas - Penelitian ACDP menemukan bahwa banyak lembaga PAUD non-formal yang tidak mampu memenuhi ke delapan standar yang ditetapkan dalam Keputusan Menteri No. 137, sebagai &nbsp
column9: oleh Kementerian, dan penelitian ACDP yang lain menunjukkan bahwa guru, keterampilan pribadi, komitmen dan afinitas pada anak-anak di dalam PAUD HI lebih mementingkan penyediaan pengajaran yang berkualitas pada tingkat tersebut daripada kualifikasi formalnya.

column1: Pilihan yang diajukan dibagi menjadi tiga tingkatan yang berbeda, Nasional, Provinsi / Kabupaten, dan Masyarakat. Tingkat nasional mencakup peningkatan penyediaan dan partisipasi dalam perawatan dan pendidikan anak usia dini, dan semakin meningkatkan pengeluaran anggaran sebagai proporsi dari total pengeluaran
column2: menciptakan Model Pengembangan yang fleksibel sebagai acuan untuk kabupaten dan desa-desa
column3: dll. Di tingkat provinsi / kabupaten misalnya Dinas Pendidikan Kabupaten harus membantu PAUD yang jelek dan baru didirikan yang tidak memiliki kemampuan membiayai sendiri dan PAUD yang menampung anak-anak dari keluarga miskin
column4: mengembangkan bank sumber daya di setiap daerah untuk menyimpan materi terkait praktek terbaik dalam pengembangan, pembiayaan dan penyelenggaraan PAUD HI
column7: pengembangan masyarakat agar berinvestasi pada PAUD dan teknik inisiatif swadana, dll. &nbsp
column9: meliputi mengajarkan orang tua pada tujuan PAUD dan PAUD HI dan memberitahu apa yang dapat meningkatkan kualitas PAUD
column10: mengidentifikasi dan mengalokasikan sumber daya ke PAUD
column11: memperkuat jangkauan Posyandu, bidan dan fasilitas kesehatan berdasarkan pada kebutuhan lokal, dll.&nbsp

column2: Pendidikan Keluarga

column1: Orang tua dan pengasuh utama lainnya memiliki pengaruh paling signifikan pada perkembangan fisik, kognitif, psikososial dan emosional anak. Setiap anak membutuhkan setidaknya satu pengasuh utama yang ia dapat percayai dan dekat dengannya untuk memiliki perkembangan yang optimal. Pendidikan keluarga atau pendidikan pengasuhan bertujuan untuk meningkatkan kesejahteraan anak dan keluarganya, sebagaimana diungkap dalam penelitiannya Harlen dkk dan Bank Dunia bahwa peran aktif orang tua dapat meningkatkan perkembangan dan hasil belajar anak. Hal ini juga terkait dengan Pengembangan Anak Usia Dini (PAUD), dimana intervensi yang dilakukan meliputi mendidik dan membantu orang tua, mengembangkan kapasitas pengasuh, dan menggunakan komunikasi masa untuk meningkatkan pengetahuan dan praktek orang tua dan pengasuh.
Sejumlah kementerian di Indonesia telah memberikan layanan peningkatan kesejahteraan anak dan keluarga pada anak-anak berusia dini seperti Kelas Ibu
column2: dari Departemen Kesehatan dan program untuk keluarga miskin dari Departemen Sosial. Meskipun ada permasalahan, pemerintah telah membangun sistem yang baik dalam layanan pendidikan anak usia dini dan program PAUD telah meningkat dan pesat selama dekade terakhir.

column1: Program pendidikan harus memiliki komponen konten, pengelolaan, dan desain yang tepat, untuk mencapai hasil yang lebih baik. Juga, penyelenggara pendidikan orangtua disarankan untuk memilih pesan kunci tertentu, bermakna dan menyesuaiakan konten untuk keluarga rentan. Rekomendasi untuk meningkatkan rancangan program dan pelaksanaan meliputi: (i) pembelajaran aktif (ii) tujuan eksplisit (iii) durasi dan intensitas yang cukup (iv) praktek (v) konten yang sesuai (vi) responsiveness (vii) dukungan masyarakat dan (viii) staf yang terlatih dan kompeten.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390393933"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390393933"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Penjaminan Mutu (QA)

column1: Penjaminan mutu merupakan proses sistematis dan efektif untuk mengetahui apakah layanan yang sedang diselenggarakan memenuhi persyaratan atau standar tertentu. Dalam rangka meningkatkan kapasitas anak-anak (dari lahir sampai usia 6 tahun) untuk berkembang dan belajar, layanan PAUD harus berkualitas tinggi dan penyedianya harus bertanggung jawab untuk memenuhi kualitas tersebut. Namun, penyelenggaraan layanan PAUD yang berkualitas masih merupakan permasalahan utama yang dihadapi Indonesia. Langkah awal untuk pengembangan sistem jaminan mutu sudah dilaksanakan dalam bentuk kerangka peraturan perundang-undangan dari pemerintah, presiden dan peraturan menteri serta rencana strategis kementerian dan Penetapan standar nasional untuk layanan PAUD . Pembentukan Direktorat Jenderal Pendidikan Anak Usia Dini dan Pendidikan Masyarakat (Dirjen PAUD DIKMAS) dalam restrukturisasi Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan merupakan contoh dari langkah tersebut. Yang penting pada tahap ini adalah memastikan efektifitas pelaksanaan peraturan ini, terutama di tingkat kabupaten dan masyarakat, serta menetapkan proses penjaminan mutu berdasarkan standar tersebut dapat tercapai.

In some parts of Indonesia, the number of the indigenous population in rural and remote areas is much smaller than the non-indigenous who live in urban and semi-urban areas. Nevertheless, census data from the Central Bureau of Statistics (BPS) shows that in year 2000, the majority of indigenous Papuans live

column2: Promising Local Practice

column1: Multigrade teaching and learning can be defined as where one teacher has responsibility of two or more grades or classes at the same time.
column2: In developing countries such as Peru, Sri Lanka, Vietnam and Indonesia, the term refers to classes where grades are combined for necessity reasons.

column1: It is a common practice in rural and remote areas throughout the world.
column2: Examples of multi-grade teaching: Finland (70% of all primary school pupils are enrolled in schools with fewer than three teachers), Portugal&nbsp
column3: (80% of pupils attend schools with no more than two classrooms), The Philippines (8% of schools are multigrade, Mexico (22% of primary schools have only one teacher), India (77% of primary schools follow the multi-grade system), Ireland (42% of schools have two or more grade levels and 16% have three or more in a class) also in the rural and remote areas of Australia, the UK and the USA.

Millions of children across Indonesia have to leave their mother tongues behind in order to learn the national language, which is not familiar to them. This signifies an uncultivated resource children bring with them when starting school, their language skills, which leads to slower and poorer learning process.

column2: Knowledge-to-Policy in 3T Areas - The Case of Sumba

column1: Based on human resource indicators, all four districts in Sumba are categorized as underdeveloped and lower than the national average. 60% of Sumba village communities are disadvantaged and 13% can be considered as remote based on their index constructed from the national village potential database (PODES).

Sumba has a good example of the educational research use to inform policies, primarily those aiming to improve education quality in disadvantaged schools. The provincial government had invited ACDP to discuss the critical concerns related to education performance in NTT, and ultimately in Sumba, based on ACDP work in rural and remote education initiatives in Papua.

column2: s readiness to learn, the proportion of untrained teachers, PNS teacher supply and distribution, and sustainable resourcing for private schools.&nbsp

column4: It also highlights the high repetition rate in Year 2 and a large amount of students having difficulties in reading.

column2: FPPS (Advocacy Forum for Sumba Education) was formed to play an important role in initiating Sumba&rsquo
column3: s policy development. It made up of the Vice Bupati in each district, the head of the Dinas Pendidikan and Bappeda in each district as the line departments supporting the policy leaders in technical aspects.&nbsp
column4: FPPS has the role of monitoring and coordinating the commitment of all districts to take policy action for education reform as well as to report on their policy adoption, resourcing, and regulation progress.

column1: Now Sumba has dedicated a mechanism for policy review and development. The districts are trained for negotiating policy positions with the central government, even though resourcing and policy implementation requires systemic capacity as well as political drivers. For technical capacity, it needs a longer time frame for development, and there are some key processes that need to be in place to sustain the policies that districts have adopted evaluation of schools and learning linked to systemic processes through the district Dinas Pendidikan, triggering intervention, strategy review, planning and budgeting

,Pendidikan di Daerah Pedesaan dan Terpencil","

Di beberapa bagian Indonesia, jumlah penduduk pribumi di daerah pedesaan dan terpencil jauh lebih kecil daripada non-pribumi yang tinggal di daerah perkotaan dan semi-perkotaan. Namun demikian, di Papua, sebagian besar penduduk asli Papua tersebar tinggal di pedesaan dan daerah terpencil (77 persen dan 64 persen masing-masing di Papua dan Papua Barat, menurut BPS
column2: Sensus 2010). Budaya masyarakat adat secara signifikan berbeda dari non-pribumi karena keterbatasan kontak dengan dunia luar sampai pertengahan abad kedua puluh. Namun, pembangunan negara secara umum belum merata, dan sebagian besar masih dilakukan di Pulau Jawa, di mana ibukota Jakarta berada. Akses internet masih di zona gelap untuk bagian timur Indonesia. Hal ini menunjukan perlunya semua pihak memiliki kepentingan untuk pengembangan pendidikan di daerah tersebut, sehingga dapat membantu mengurangi kesenjangan.

Beberapa opsi yang diajukan adalah meningkatkan strategi ruang kelas, mengembangkan bahan pembelajaran yang tepat, dan membuat program-program pengembangan guru.
Ada beberapa program seperti: SERASI, yang menyediakan layanan kesehatan dasar dan pendidikan, memastikan pengelolaan dana desa yang transparan, dan mengadakan pembentukan kapasitas
column3: IPPM - Sekolah Kampung, cara yang tepat untuk memberikan layanan pendidikan lebih dekat ke desa-desa terpencil di Papua adalah dengan mendirikan sekolah-sekolah kampung di tiga desa (Betaf, Beneraf dan Yamna) di Kecamatan Pantai Timur - Kabupaten Sarmi dan melibatkan pemangku kepentingan setempat untuk membantu pelaksanaan sekolah kampung
column4: dan Summer Institute of Linguistic (SIL International): Mapping of Language Communities and Schools, sebuah LSM yang memiliki status konsultatif dengan UNESCO, berupaya untuk memberdayakan masyarakat bahasa minoritas melalui program penelitian dan literasi, membantu masyarakat memperkenalkan bahasa mereka, memberikan pendidikan dan pengembangan dengan melestarikan keunikan budaya dan bahasa. Program ini aktif dalam pembentukan linguistik dan peta sekolah - kegiatan yang penting untuk koordinasi dan perencanaan penyediaan layanan sosial dan pendidikan di Papua yang efektif.&nbsp

column1: Ada juga pilihan untuk meningkatkan tata kelola saat ini dalam sistem desentralisasi. Reformasi yang bersifat luas dan kompleks perlu disertai dengan program pengembangan kapasitas yang signifikan. Tata Kelola diterapkan untuk dinas pendidikan dari mulai provinsi ke kabupaten, kecamatan ke tingkat sekolah, dan juga sistem yang lebih luas yang terlibat dalam proses pemerintahan. Kedua kebijakan yang signifikan yang mempengaruhi permasalahan tata kelola dan pemerataan adalah: (i) peningkatan alokasi dana Otonomi Khusus (Otsus) ke kabupaten (ii) 5% dari 80% yang ditransfer ke kabupaten akan dialokasikan untuk layanan pendidikan yang diselenggarakan melalui yayasan keagamaan.

column2: Pengetahuan-untuk-Kebijakan di Daerah 3T - Kasus di Sumba

column1: Berdasarkan indikator sumber daya manusia, ke empat kabupaten di Sumba dikategorikan sebagai tertinggal dan lebih rendah dari rata-rata nasional. 60% merupakan masyarakat tertinggal dan 13% merupakan masyarakat terpencil berdasarkan indeks basis data tentang potensi desa secara nasional (PODES).

Sumba memiliki contoh penelitian pendidikan yang baik untuk menginformasikan kebijakan, terutama yang bertujuan untuk meningkatkan kualitas pendidikan di sekolah-sekolah tertinggal. Pemerintah provinsi mengundang ACDP untuk membahas masalah penting terkait kinerja pendidikan di NTT, dan termasuk Sumba, berdasarkan penelitian ACDP dalam inisiatif pendidikan pedesaan dan terpencil di Papua. &nbsp

Permasalahan yang ada diantaranya terkait kualitas pengajaran, kesiapan anak untuk belajar, proporsi guru terlatih, ketersediaan dan pemerataan guru PNS, dan bantuan berkelanjutan untuk sekolah swasta. Pilihan yang diusulkan yaitu, Analisis Situasi yang Komprehensif (CSA), yang memberikan contoh situasi di sekolah dasar Sumba dalam mengembangkan pilihan kebijakan. Analisis
column2: ini juga menyoroti tingkat pengulangan yang tinggi di Tahun ke 2 karena banyaknya siswa mengalami kesulitan dalam membaca.

column1: Forum Peduli Pendidikan Sumba - FPPS didirikan untuk memainkan peran penting dalam membantu pengembangan kebijakan di Sumba. Forum ini terdiri dari Wakil Bupati dari setiap kabupaten, kepala Dinas Pendidikan dan Bappeda di setiap kabupaten untuk mendukung para pemimpin kebijakan dalam aspek teknis. FPPS memiliki peran memonitor dan mengkordinasikan komitmen semua kabupaten untuk ikut serta dalam reformasi pendidikan serta melaporkan perkembangan pengambilan kebijakan, pembiayaan, dan regulasinya.
Sekarang Sumba memiliki mekanisme untuk meninjau dan mengembangkan kebijakan. Kabupaten dilatih untuk menegosiasikan kedudukan
column2: kebijakan dengan pemerintah pusat, meskipun pembiayaan dan pelaksanaan kebijakan memerlukan kemampuan sistemik serta penggerak politik. Untuk kapasitas teknis, perlu kerangka waktu yang lebih lama untuk pengembangan, dan ada beberapa proses utama yang &nbsp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390408435"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390408435"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
Exemplary school principals are an important factor in improving school effectiveness and enhancing quality. Indonesia&rsquo
column2: s Ministerial Regulation 44/2002 mandated school-based management, making the principal the key decision maker. These include finance and budgeting, staff management, school planning, and curriculum development roles. It thus requires principals to have upgraded skills. Principals Preparation Program (PPP) is conducted to ensure those eligible to become principals are ready for the job.

column1: Two aspects of PPP considered effective are Nomor Unik Kepala Sekolah (NUKS), an official principal registration number, and PPP mentoring program. Some issues persist, including the fact that principals are applying the administrative requirements and education policy routinely, but not the skills and knowledge of instructional leaders.
column2: Also, in terms of PPP, unfortunately, the degree of political and bureaucratic involvement in identifying applicants into PPP and in the appointment of school principals was a problem. An option worth considering is to have LPPKS be more diligent about the Master Trainers&rsquo

column9: . School supervisors are required to meet Minimum Service Standards (MSS), and the competencies required of school supervisors are further defined in Ministerial Decree 12/2007. The aforementioned Ministerial Regulation No. 21 of 2010 also outlines the main tasks of supervisors, which include monitoring the implementation of Indonesia&rsquo

column1: The key challenge suggested by many publications on school supervision in Indonesia is the recruitment process.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390408429"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390408429"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Teacher Management

column1: Strategic plan for the improvement of Indonesia&rsquo
column2: s education system includes the issues of teacher management and development. Teachers as the gatekeepers of classrooms are the epicenter of students&rsquo
column3: learning process. Absence of a proper management system may lead not only to a worsened learning process, but also costs. Improvement of teacher management cannot come solely from teachers. Indeed, a majority of possible improvements require the right decisions and implementations by school administrators and policymakers.

column1: Teacher management issues in Indonesia can be grouped into four major areas: supply, quality, distribution, and cost. These include uneven distribution of teachers, which lead to both oversupply and lower productivity. The lack of monitoring system leads to teachers&rsquo
column2: declining quality. 24-hour rule and school-hour teacher meetings lead to <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column4: id=20"" target=""_blank"">teacher absenteeism. There is also a significant increase in the cost of employing teachers and the overall education budget, which was the result of ongoing teacher certification program guaranteeing certified teachers a professional allowance equivalent to their basic pay.

column1: Certainly, there are ways to fix these issues. Oversupply, for instance, can be fixed by not replacing teachers in schools that are already overstaffed. Allocating future teachers based on Teacher-Student ratio would also help. In terms of quality control, the 24-hour rule needs to be changed, and teachers should be qualified to teach two subjects. School principals and supervisors need to be trained in quality assurance in order to better utilize teachers&rsquo
column2: time outside class when they are at schools. Last but not least, a review that measures the impact of complicated funding system for the salaries of the various types of teachers (PNS, contract and honorary) is required the issue of costs. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column2: Diversity and Harmony
s unique characteristics is diversity, which can be seen in terms of culture, religions&nbsp
column4: The government has committed in ensuring the religious tolerance among religions in Indonesia.&nbsp
column5: Since religion is dynamic, it must be maintained. &nbsp
column6: Although there are still problems of tolerance in Indonesia, a survey by Ministry of Religious Affairs in 2015, intended to measure and provide a snapshot of Religious Tolerance (Kerukunan Umat Beragama/KUB) in the provincial capitals, showed that religious tolerance in Indonesia is still quite high (75.36 out of 100). &nbsp
column7: The government and public have the same interest in creating harmony, managing diversity and maintaining tolerance.

column1: In addition, according to a number of studies, education is the best method to
column3: id=36"" target=""_blank"">address intolerance and violence. At the higher level, education plays an important role in shaping tolerance towards diversity and foster harmony in the society.
column4: The Ministry of Religious Affairs has been working with the Kwartir Nasional in organizing Wirakarya Camping of Religious Higher Education (Perkemahan Wirakarya Perguruan Tinggi Keagamaan), where many Islamic and non-Islamic higher education institutions participate. &nbsp
column5: This activity aims to increase religious tolerance with higher-education students. Countries such as Malaysia, Morocco, and the United Kingdom have combined peace into their curriculum based on social, cultural, historical, and environmental context of each country. &nbsp
column6: These three countries introduce education on values and culture of peace through religious education.

column2: Family Education

column1: Parents and other primary caregivers have the most significant influence on a child&rsquo
column2: s physical, cognitive, psychosocial and emotional development. &nbsp
column3: Each child needs at least one primary caregiver whom he or she can trust and is close to in order to have an optimal development. &nbsp
column4: Family education or parenting education aims to improve the child and the family&rsquo
column5: s well-being, which can be found in the studies by Harlen et. Al and the World Bank that show parents&rsquo
column6: active role can improve a child&rsquo
column7: s development and learning outcomes. It is also related to <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column9: id=38"" target=""_blank"">Early Childhood Development (ECD), which interventions include educating and supporting parents, developing the capacities of caregivers, and using mass communication to enhance parents and caregivers&rsquo

column1: A number of ministries in Indonesia have provided services to improve child and family well-being in children early years such as Kelas Ibu (Mother Class) by Ministry of Health and programs that are targeted for poor families by Ministry of Social Affairs. Although
column2: there are challenges, the government has built a solid system of early childhood education &nbsp
column3: services and ECD programs have increased and exceeded over the last decade.

column1: Education programs need to have the right content, delivery
column2: and design components, to reach better results. &nbsp
column3: Also, parenting education providers are recommended to choose a specific, meaningful set of key messages and adapt content for particularly vulnerable families. &nbsp
column4: Recommendations to improve program design and implementation include: (i) active learning (ii) explicit goals (iii) sufficient duration and intensity (iv) practice (v) appropriate content (vi) responsiveness (vii) community support and (viii) trained and competent staff.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390408422"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390408422"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Quality Assurance (QA) in Early Childhood Education

column1: QA refers to a systematic and effective process of checking to see whether a service being developed is meeting specified requirements or standards. In order to improve the capacity of children (from birth to 6 years of age) to develop and learn,
column4: services should be of high quality and the providers need to be held accountable for such quality. However, the provision of high-quality ECE services is still a major challenge facing Indonesia. The initial step for the development of a QA system has already been taken in the form of the regulatory framework from the constitution itself to government, presidential and ministerial regulations and the ministry&rsquo
column5: s strategic plan as well as the establishing of national standards for ECE services. The establishment of a Directorate General of Early Childhood Education and Community Education (DGPAUD DIKMAS) in the restructuring of MoEC is an example of such move. What is critical at this stage is to ensure the effective implementation of these regulations, particularly at the decentralised district and community levels, as well as to establish the processes to assure the quality aligned to such standards is being achieved.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390408419"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390408419"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Basic Education Minimum Service Standards
s 12-year compulsory education program is trying to build the success of its 9-year compulsory education program to achieve universal basic education.&nbsp
column3: However, basic education services offered in both urban and rural areas have very poor quality and lack relevance to the social and economic conditions in the areas. To address the concerns regarding quality, the government has applied several programs in recent years.&nbsp
column4: The Minimum Service Standards (MSS) aims to ensure that every school and madrasah meets at least the minimum conditions needed for quality teaching and learning to occur.

column1: There are major shortfalls against minimum service standards, with no schools meeting them. A study bu EU-ADB Minimum Service Standards Capacity Development Program (MSS-CDP) found that schools in almost all areas had difficulties meeting the standards related to providing some of the key facilities and teaching resources. Books and, particularly, facilities and equipment for science teaching at both elementary and junior secondary level are too often in short supply. Critical shortfalls have been found not only in school resources and infrastructure, but also in important educational processes especially in areas such as supervision, lesson planning, and student assessment.
A recent OECD review of the Indonesian education system also found that currently parents and the community do not pay attention to the quality of schooling
column2: instead, they mainly want for their children to gain an education certificate. Neither parents nor school committees are currently actively involved in school decision making and activities.

column1: Some possible options to address these issue include implementing a longer-term strategy to ensure that all basic education schools/madrasahs have the facilities, including buildings and basic equipment, specified in MSS. Adjustment of
column3: id=1"" target=""_blank"">BOS payments to reflect the different operational costs of schools and madrasahs of different sizes and in different geographical areas may also be effective. In terms of gaining parents&rsquo
column4: attention, continuous socialisation and increased understanding of and commitment to the MSS among all key stakeholders, including parents, is a viable strategy. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499390408415"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499390408415"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Indonesia Qualifications Framework

column1: Many countries seek to establish qualifications frameworks in order to increase the global mobility of workers. Qualifications framework sets standards and criteria for a nation&rsquo
column2: s agreed qualifications and allow skills and qualifications gained elsewhere to be acknowledged. The Indonesian Qualifications Framework (IQF) was established to respond to national needs and regional and global trends of economic integration. The three main players in developing Indonesia&rsquo
column3: s qualification framework are the Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC), Ministry of Manpower (MoM) and the Ministry of Research, Technology and Higher Education (MoRTHE).

column1: The current stage of implementation of IQF varies among different sectors in Indonesia. Yet, issues such as Indonesia&rsquo
column2: s manpower challenge continues to be a burden. There is a mismatch between education outcomes and workforce needs in Indonesia. Employers have also reported disparities in the quality and types of skills graduates attain at university. University graduates with similar qualifications often have acquired considerably different sets of skills and knowledge, and there are large variations in standards. There needs to be a quality assurance process and a national qualification framework. This will help both universities and employers. Establishment of the Indonesian Qualification Board (IQB) to coordinate all activities related to IQF and ensure synergetic effort, particularly to cope with the challenges of ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) implementation, would be useful.
