column1: Akses ke sekolah di daerah pedesaan dan terpencil
• Sejumlah besar anak-anak, terutama di daerah pedesaan dan terpencil, masih kekurangan akses pada pendidikan.

• Tingkat partisipasi sekolah anak usia 5-14 tahun sama antara daerah perkotaan dan pedesaan. Namun, sementara 72% anak berusia 15-19 tahun di perkotaan berpartisipasi dalam pendidikan, dan 63% anak yang berpartisipasi di daerah pedesaan.

• Sebagian besar populasi di Papua dan Papua Barat tinggal di desa-desa terpencil, dimana hanya 77% dari anak-anak mendaftar di sekolah dasar dan hanya 27% mendaftarkan diri di sekolah menengah pertama.
• Jarak ke Sekolah dan transportasi yang terbatas menyebabkan anak-anak meninggalkan pendidikan formal
• Ketidakhadiran guru, rendahnya kualitas pelayanan pendidikan dan fasilitas, kemiskinan dan kebutuhan anak-anak membantu pendapatan keluarga.

<li>BOS memiliki peran signifikan dalam meningkatkan akses serta memastikan bahwa sekolah memiliki anggaran operasional. Namun, BOS seringkali tidak mencukupi untuk daerah pedesaan dan terpencil seperti Maluku dan Papua di mana biayaoperasional &nbsp
column2: lebih tinggi daripada di daerah lain di Indonesia.

column1: • meninjau pengalokasian BOS agar memperhatikan perbedaan kapasitas pendapatan dan biaya sekolah yang lebih besar tergantung lokasi, besaran, dan jumlah siswa,
• meningkatkan fleksibilitas jadwal sekolah dan jadwal masyarakat di pedesaan dan daerah-daerah terpencil agar waktu sekolah tidak bertentangan dengan kalender pertanian atau kegiatan ekonomi.

• Melakukan evaluasi efektivitas berbagai program untuk menghubungkan masyarakat pedesaan dan terpencil, sekolah dan pusat pembelajaran, mengembangkan komunikasi modern baik melalui telekomunikasi maupun internet. Teknologi ini memiliki peran yang kuat dalam penyediaan layanan dan peningkatan kualitas di semua tingkat pendidikan.
Kualitas pendidikan di daerah pedesaan dan terpencil
• Guru di daerah pedesaan dan terpencil cenderung kurang berpendidikan dibandingkan guru di daerah perkotaan.
• Kepala sekolah di daerah pedesaan dan daerah tertinggal lebih banyak memiliki kekurangan atau sumber daya yang tidak memadai dibanding kepala sekolah di daerah perkotaan dan daerah maju.

• Banyak daerah pedesaan memiliki rasio siswa-guru yang rendah karena daerah ini memiliki banyak sekolah kecil. Meskipun jumlah siswa yang sedikit, sekolah-sekolah ini dikelola sesuai dengan aturan pengelolaan sekolah dasar yang mengharuskan adanya minimal sembilan guru. Sementara, masih banyak sekolah, terutama di daerah terpencil, yang mengalami kekurangan guru.

14,"1","Knowledge-to-policy in 3T Areas The Case of Sumba","

Based on the human resource indicators, all four districts in Sumba are categorized as underdeveloped lower than the national average. 60% of Sumba village communities are disadvantaged and 13% can be considered as remote based on their index constructed from the national village potential database (PODES).

Sumba has a good example of the educational research use to inform policies, primarily those aiming to improve education quality in disadvantaged schools. The provincial government had invited the Education and Sector Analytical and Capacity Development Partnership (ACDP) to discuss the critical concerns related to education performance in East Nusa Tenggara (NTT), and ultimately in Sumba, based on ACDP work in rural and remote education initiatives in Papua.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499158930998"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499158930998"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

column2: Proposed Options

column1: • The Comprehensive Situation Analysis (CSA) provides the situation evidence in Sumba primary schools to develop policy options. It also highlights the high repetition rate in Year 2 and a large amount of students having difficulties in reading. Repetition rate differs from 12% to 21% in the four districts and about 30% of Year 2 students have difficulties in reading in the sample schools. The high repetition rate and low reading abilities show low learning quality in the early grades. To monitor if students have the basic foundation for future learning, they need to take test in Year 2 or 3.

Students do better in listening to texts being read aloud in their mother tongue than in reading tests in Bahasa Indonesia. About 75% students were able to answer correctly more than 50% of the oral comprehension questions. Students who are not familiar with the language written structure and vocabulary, they use their speaking and listening ability in their mother tongue as the basic potential to develop reading comprehension. The study also found the

column1: All districts took important steps in policy development prioritizing three of the most important policy areas. which are (i) the continuous professional development for early grade teachers, especially in teaching literacy, through teacher working group (KKG)
column2: (ii) efforts towards equalized quality teachers distribution for disadvantaged schools
FPPS (Advocacy Forum for Sumba Education) was formed to play an important role in initiating Sumba&rsquo
column3: s policy development. It made up of the Vice Bupati in each district, the head of the Dinas Pendidikan and Bappeda in each district as the line departments supporting the policy leaders in technical aspects. FPPS has the role of monitoring and coordinating the commitment of all districts to take policy action for education reform as well as to report on their policy adoption, resourcing, and regulation progress. FPPS has prepared official letters to the Minister of Education and Culture seeking for his support for the consideration of a set of policy adjustments.

column1: • The Future of Education Policy Development in Sumba

Now Sumba has dedicated a mechanism for policy review and development. The districts are trained for negotiating policy positions with the central government, even though resourcing and policy implementation requires systemic capacity as well as political drivers. For technical capacity, it needs a longer time frame for development, and there are some key processes that need to be in place to sustain the policies that districts have adopted:
• Evaluation of schools and learning linked to systemic processes through the district Dinas Pendidikan, triggering intervention, strategy review, planning and budgeting
• Government-wide usage of Dapodik data, as the comprehensive source for planning and projections

National policies that impact fiscal capacity of the districts must also be reviewed in order for the districts to adequately resource quality development. Other national policies, such as in the PAUD sector and the village fund allocation, may also require significant adjustment to yield the potential for improvement in educational quality.

,Pengetahuan-untuk-Kebijakan di Daerah 3T - Kasus di Sumba","

Berdasarkan indikator sumber daya manusia, ke empat kabupaten di Sumba dikategorikan sebagai tertinggal dan lebih rendah dari rata-rata nasional. 60% merupakan masyarakat tertinggal dan 13% merupakan masyarakat terpencil berdasarkan indeks basis data tentang potensi desa secara nasional (PODES).

Sumba memiliki contoh penelitian pendidikan yang baik untuk menginformasikan kebijakan, terutama yang bertujuan untuk meningkatkan kualitas pendidikan di sekolah-sekolah tertinggal. Pemerintah provinsi mengundang ACDP untuk membahas masalah penting terkait kinerja pendidikan di NTT, dan termasuk Sumba, berdasarkan penelitian ACDP dalam inisiatif pendidikan pedesaan dan terpencil di Papua.

Tingkat pengulangan yang tinggi dan kemampuan membaca yang rendah menunjukkan kualitas belajar yang rendah di kelas awal. Penelitian ini juga menunjukan adanya manfaat pendidikan anak usia dini (PAUD) dan adanya kebutuhan akan penyediaan pendidikan yang berkualitas untuk membantu kesiapan sekolah.

column1: Forum Peduli Pendidikan Sumba - FPPS didirikan untuk memainkan peran penting dalam membantu pengembangan kebijakan di Sumba. Forum ini terdiri dari Wakil Bupati dari setiap kabupaten, kepala Dinas Pendidikan dan Bappeda di setiap kabupaten untuk mendukung para pemimpin kebijakan dalam aspek teknis. FPPS memiliki peran memonitor dan mengkordinasikan komitmen semua kabupaten untuk ikut serta dalam reformasi pendidikan serta melaporkan perkembangan pengambilan kebijakan, pembiayaan, dan regulasinya. FPPS telah membuat surat resmi kepada Menteri Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan meminta bantuan untuk mempertimbangkan serangkaian penyesuaian pada kebijakan.
• Masa Depan Pengembangan Kebijakan Pendidikan di Sumba
Sekarang Sumba memiliki mekanisme untuk meninjau dan mengembangkan kebijakan. Kabupaten dilatih untuk menegosiasikan kedudukan
column2: kebijakan dengan pemerintah pusat, meskipun pembiayaan dan pelaksanaan kebijakan memerlukan kemampuan sistemik serta penggerak politik. Untuk kapasitas teknis, perlu kerangka waktu yang lebih lama untuk pengembangan, dan ada beberapa proses utama yang&nbsp
column3: harus ada untuk mempertahankan kebijakan yang sudah digunakan oleh kabupaten:

column1: • Penilaian sekolah dan pembelajaran terkait dengan proses sistemik melalui Dinas Pendidikan daerah, yang memicu intervensi, tinjauan strategi, perencanaan dan penganggaran
• Pemerintah menggunakan data Dapodik sebagai sumber komprehensif untuk perencanaan dan proyeksi

Kebijakan nasional lainnya, seperti pada sektor PAUD dan alokasi dana desa, mungkin juga membutuhkan penyesuaian yang signifikan agar memiliki andil dalam peningkatan kualitas pendidikan.

15,"1","Teacher Workforce Planning and Distribution","

A fair distribution of qualified teachers is a complex issue in Indonesia&rsquo
column2: s educational system where private schools play an important role in educational provision, specifically in remote rural areas. In the past, most formal education was provided primarily by private faith-based organizations. Recognizing the importance of private provision in Indonesia&rsquo
column3: s education system, the Government has sought to balance the quality of private and public education through several policy actions, including the BOS and placing PNS teachers in private schools. These PNS teachers are called &ldquo
column4: guru PNS yang dipekerjakan&rdquo
column5: (DPK teachers), DPK teachers make up half of the teachers. The proportion of PNS and non-PNS teachers in public and private schools varies by district. In the Sumba districts overall, 45% of teachers in government schools are PNS and 40% of teachers in private schools are PNS.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149929324"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149929324"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

• In February 2016, the government of Pekalongan district Central Java withdrew DPK teachers, an action that received harsh criticism from the Forum for Private Education Institutions (Badan Musyawarah Perguruan Swasta or BMPS). Despite joint ministerial decrees in 2014 and a letter from the Minister of Education formalizing and supporting the placement of PNS teachers in private schools in mid-2016, this issue has been resurfacing.
<li>In mid-January of 2017, the Government made a public statement that would affect DPK teachers. The statement described the Government&rsquo
column2: s intention to reinforce Government Regulation 53/2010 strictly. This regulation restricts PNS to serve in government entities exclusively. When applied to teachers, the impact would be to deploy them to government schools instead.

column1: <li>Re-deploying DPK teachers to government schools will adversely affect the <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column3: id=15"" target=""_blank"">3T areas (predominantly outermost, isolated, underdeveloped areas), as may be demonstrated by the case of Central Sumba where the mandate would translate to the district losing half of the teachers in their private schools.

column1: <li>This most recent public statement directing PNS teachers to return to government schools is the latest iteration of similar statements in a string of central and local governments&rsquo
column2: inconsistencies on messages to the public regarding DPK teachers. It signals perhaps an ongoing policy conversation and debate over how to interpret regulatory frameworks governing the distribution of PNS teachers, and what sectoral adjustments are needed.

column1: • There are inconsistencies in policies emanating from different levels in the hierarchy of legal products: government regulations or Peraturan Pemerintah, Laws or Undang-Undang, and Ministerial Decrees or Peraturan Menteri. This gives the impression that ministries are pulling in different directions on the issue. It has created confusion at the district level that is exacerbated by rumors, misinterpretation of public statements, and a tendency to take public statements as new regulations.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149929324"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149929324"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: There is a need for clarity on the placement of PNS teachers in private schools at the policy, legal, and regulatory levels. More importantly, there is a need for careful consideration regarding how the legal and regulatory framework pertaining to PNS teacher management and distribution will be interpreted at the local level. The risk is that rigid application of overall PNS management policies to DPK teachers will doubly disadvantage children in rural remote areas. Those children are already disadvantaged simply by residing in resource poor areas. To withdraw qualified teachers from their schools would further deprive them of one resource that could help them to improve their lives now and in the future.

,Perencanaan dan Penyebaran Tenaga Kerja Guru","

Penyebaran guru
column3: merupakan masalah yang kompleks pada sistem pendidikan di Indonesia di mana sekolah swasta memainkan peran penting dalam penyediaan pendidikan, khususnya di daerah pedesaan terpencil. Di masa lalu, sebagian besar pendidikan formal diberikan terutama oleh organisasi swasta berbasis keagamaan. Mengingat pentingnya penyediaan sistem pendidikan swasta di Indonesia, Pemerintah berupaya untuk menyeimbangkan kualitas pendidikan swasta dan negeri melalui beberapa langkah kebijakan, termasuk BOS dan menempatkan guru PNS di sekolah swasta. Guru-guru PNS ini disebut &ldquo
column4: guru PNS Yang dipekerjakan &rdquo
column5: ( DPK guru), guru DPK berjumlah setengah dari guru. Proporsi PNS dan non - guru PNS di sekolah negeri dan swasta bervariasi tiap kabupaten. Di kabupaten Sumba keseluruhan, 45% guru di sekolah-sekolah pemerintah berstatus&nbsp
column6: PNS dan 40% guru di sekolah swasta adalah PNS.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149929336"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149929336"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

• Pada bulan Februari 2016, Pemerintah Kabupaten Pekalongan Jawa Tengah melakukan penarikan guru DPK, tindakan yang mendapat kritik keras dari Badan Musyawarah Perguruan Swasta atau BMPS). Meskipun keputusan menteri bersama pada tahun 2014 dan surat Menteri Pendidikan memformalkan dan mendukung penempatan guru PNS di sekolah swasta pada pertengahan 2016, masalah ini telah muncul lagi.

• Pada pertengahan Januari 2017, Pemerintah membuat pernyataan yang mempengaruhi guru DPK. Pernyataan itu menggambarkan niat Pemerintah untuk melaksanakan Peraturan Pemerintah Nomor 53/2010 dengan ketat. Peraturan ini membatasi PNS untuk kerja di lembaga pemerintah secara eksklusif. Bila diterapkan, dampaknya akan menempatkan guru di sekolah-sekolah negeri.

• Penarikan guru DPK kembali ke sekolah-sekolah negeri akan mempengaruhi daerah 3T (terutama terluar, terpencil, daerah tertinggal), sebagaimana contoh kasus Sumba Tengah di mana kebijakan ini mengakibatkan kabupaten kehilangan setengah dari guru dari sekolah swasta.

• Pernyataan pemerintah yang meminta guru PNS untuk kembali ke sekolah negeri merupakan iterasi terbaru pernyataan serupa yang menunjukan inkonsistensi serangkaian pernyataan pemerintah pusat dan daerah kepada masyarakat mengenai guru DPK. Ini menunjukan adanya pembicaraan dan perdebatan kebijakan yang sedang berlangsung tentang kerangka peraturan yang mengatur penyebaran guru PNS, dan penyesuaian yang diperlukan.

• Ada inkonsistensi kebijakan yang berasal dari tingkat hirarki produk hukum yang berbeda: Peraturan Pemerintah, Hukum atau Undang-Undang, dan Keputusan Menteri atau Peraturan Menteri. Hal ini memberikan kesan bahwa kementerian memiliki arah yang berbeda pada masalah ini. Hal ini memunculkan kebingungan di tingkat kabupaten yang diperburuk oleh rumor, salah menafsirkan pernyataan publik, dan kecenderungan mengambil pernyataan publik sebagai peraturan baru.

column1: Pilihan yang diusulkan meliputi kebutuhan kejelasan, hukum, dan tingkat regulasi untuk kebijakan penempatan guru PNS di sekolah swasta. Lebih penting lagi, ada kebutuhan untuk melihat bagaimana kerangka hukum dan peraturan yang berkaitan dengan manajemen dan distribusi guru PNS yang diterapkan di tingkat lokal. Risiko penerapan kebijakan manajemen PNS yang kaku tentang guru DPK menempatkan anak-anak di daerah terpencil pedesaan di posisi yang kurang menguntungkan. Anak-anak dirugikan hanya karena berada di daerah miskin sumber daya. Menarik guru berkualitas dari sekolah mereka akan lebih menjauhkan mereka dari sumber daya yang dapat membantu mereka memperbaiki kehidupan mereka sekarang dan

column1:
16,"1","Principal Effectiveness","

Exemplary school principals are an important factor in improving school effectiveness and enhancing quality. Indonesia&rsquo
column3: Decree 044/U/2002 mandated school-based management, making the principal the key decision maker. These include finance and budgeting, staff management, school planning, and curriculum development roles, thus requiring principals to have upgraded skills. Principals Preparation Program (PPP) is conducted to ensure those eligible to become principals are ready for the job. The program has an explicit purpose: coherence between content and goals, the right balance of theory and practice, appropriate admissions criteria, and a focus on continuing assessment.

column1: Two aspects of PPP considered effective are Nomor Unik Kepala Sekolah (NUKS), an official principal registration number, and PPP mentoring program. Teachers who successfully complete professional learning will receive a NUKS, which indicates a teacher as eligible to become school principal. NUKS is considered prestigious and clear in terms of standards. Mentoring program, on the other hand, is conducted in part by Master Trainers, who are trained, accredited and employed by LPPKS (principal development instituition).

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499139744866"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499139744866"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
<li>Principals are applying the administrative requirements and education policy routinely, but not the skills and knowledge of instructional leaders.&nbsp
column3: s Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC) has recognized the importance of developing exemplary principals.

column1: <li>In terms of PPP, unfortunately, the degree of political and bureaucratic involvement in identifying applicants into PPP and in the appointment of school principals was a problem.&nbsp
column2: However, based on data from LPPKS, only between 1.2% and 2.1% of all principals had a NUKS in 2014/2015.

column1: <li>However, many respondents claimed that Master Trainers did not always attend training sessions, and when they did attend, they were often more focused on messages related to their full-time jobs than focused on their work as Master Trainers.&nbsp

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499139744862"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499139744862"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: LPPKS, first of all, needs to be recognized as the helming national agency in Indonesia for building capabilities of school leaders.
Its practices have to be redirected to, among others, accredit institutions to train candidate principals and train the trainers located in the districts.
To implement these new practices, LPPKS will need to, among others, develop a strategic plan for 2016-2020 that includes targets and key performance indicators
There needs to be a revision and increased adherence to Ministry of National Education
Among the revisions is reconceptualization of the role of school principals as a career path rather than a temporary administrative position.
An increased status of Regulation 28/2010 to a Government or Presidential Decree may also be a way to improve adherence.
There also needs to be implementation of merit selection processes for recruitment and selection into PPP.
This can be achieved through increasing the role of electronic media in the socilaisation and selection process, as well as enabling online applications, among others.
PPP training needs to be delivered in the districts.
This requires, certainly, the development of capacity of provincial and district officers to support PPP.
Another way to achieve this is also to train exemplary principals and supervisors to be Mentors, Coaches and Assessors.
National administration of the NUKS is required.
PPP graduates should be appointed as principals no later than two years after they receive a NUKS.

column1:
,Efektivitas Kepala Sekolah","

Kepala sekolah teladan merupakan faktor penting dalam meningkatkan efektivitas dan peningkatan mutu
column4: berbasis sekolah, yang menempatkan kepala sekolah sebagai pembuat keputusan utama&nbsp
column5: misalnya dalam urusan keuangan dan penganggaran, manajemen staf, perencanaan sekolah, dan peran pengembangan kurikulum. Karenanya kepala sekolah harus senantiasa meningkatkan keterampilannya. Program Persiapan Kepala Sekolah (PPKS) diadakan untuk memastikan mereka yang memenuhi syarat menjadi kepala sekolah adalah yang siap untuk pekerjaan itu. Program ini memiliki tujuan: koherensi antara konten dan tujuan, keseimbangan antara teori dan praktek, kriteria penerimaan yang tepat, dan fokus pada penilaian berkelanjutan.

column1: Dua aspek PPKS yang dianggap penting yaitu Nomor Unik Kepala Sekolah (NUKS), sebuah nomor resmi pendaftaran kepala sekolah, dan program mentoring PPKS. Guru yang berhasil menyelesaikan pembelajaran profesi akan menerima NUKS, sebagai bukti bahwa guru memenuhi syarat untuk menjadi kepala sekolah. NUKS dianggap penting dan jelas menurut standar. Program mentoring, di sisi lain, dilakukan sebagian oleh Master Trainer, yang terlatih, terakreditasi dan dipekerjakan oleh LPPKS.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499139779298"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499139779298"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

<li>Kepala sekolah memenuhi ketentuan administrasi dan kebijakan pendidikan, tetapi tidak memiliki keterampilan dan pengetahuan tentang pemimpin pendidikan. Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan menyadari pentingya&nbsp

• Dalam hal PPKS, sayangnya, tingkat keterlibatan politik dan birokrasi dalam menentukan calon peserta PPKS dan pengangkatan kepala sekolah menjadikannya bermasalah. Akan tetapi, berdasarkan data dari LPPKS, hanya antara 1,2% dan 2,1% dari semua kepala sekolah memiliki NUKS di 2014/2015.
<li>Banyak responden menyatakan bahwa Master Trainer tidak selalu menghadiri sesi pelatihan, dan ketika mereka hadir, mereka tidak fokus&nbsp
column2: pada pekerjaan mereka sebagai Master Trainer.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499139835846"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499139835846"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: <li>LPPKS, pertama-tama, perlu diakui sebagai badan nasional pemungutan suara di Indonesia untuk membangun kemampuan para pemimpin sekolah.
• Praktiknya harus diarahkan, antara lain, mengakreditasi institusi untuk melatih calon kepala sekolah dan melatih pelatih yang berada di kabupaten.
• Untuk menerapkan praktik baru ini, LPPKS perlu, antara lain, mengembangkan rencana strategis untuk tahun 2016-2020 yang mencakup target dan indikator kinerja utama.
<li>Perlu ada revisi dan peningkatan kepatuhan terhadap Peraturan Menteri Pendidikan Nasional 28/2010.
• Diantara revisi tersebut adalah rekonseptualisasi peran kepala sekolah sebagai jalur karir daripada posisi administratif sementara.
• Peningkatan status Peraturan 28/2010 ke Pemerintah atau Keputusan Presiden juga bisa menjadi cara untuk meningkatkan kepatuhan.
<li>Perlu juga dilakukan penerapan proses seleksi merit untuk rekrutmen dan seleksi ke PPP.
• Hal ini dapat dicapai melalui peningkatan peran media elektronik dalam proses sosialisasi dan seleksi, serta memungkinkan aplikasi online, antara lain.
• Ini tentu saja memerlukan pengembangan kapasitas perwira provinsi dan kabupaten untuk mendukung PPP.
• Cara lain untuk mencapainya adalah dengan melatih para pelaku dan atasan teladan untuk menjadi Mentor, Pelatih dan Penilai.
• Lulusan PPP harus ditunjuk sebagai kepala sekolah paling lambat dua tahun setelah mereka menerima NUKS.

17,"1","School Supervisors","

School supervisors play an essential role in an education system. They are expected to act as both education managers and &lsquo
column3: . They need to ensure application of education standards such as 1) inspecting and evaluating, and 2) advising, assisting, and supporting teachers and school leadership. The globally continuing debate is whether school supervisors should focus one or the other.

column2: of Administrative and Bureaucratic Reform Regulation 21/2010
column4: civil servant...responsible&hellip
column5: to conduct academic and managerial supervision on education units&rdquo
column6: . School supervisors are required to meet <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column8: id=43"" target=""_blank"">Minimum Service Standards (MSS), and the competencies required of school supervisors are further defined in Ministerial Decree 12/2007. Ministerial Regulation 21/2010 also outlines the main tasks of supervisors, which include monitoring the implementation of Indonesia&rsquo
column9: s eight National Education Standards, among others.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499140602525"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499140602525"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
The key challenge suggested by many publications on school supervision in Indonesia is the recruitment process. Some suggested that supervisors should have experience in school leadership positions.

A 2013 by the Education Sector Analytical and Capacity Development Partnership (ACDP) survey of supervisors and principals validated that supervisors were deficient in competencies needed to improve learning. The survey rated supervisors (through self-ratings and ratings by teachers and principals) on, among others, personality/character, social (taking an active role in the supervisors&rsquo
column2: association, etc.), and managerial as well as academic supervision.

column1: Points of challenges identified through the survey:

column4: Personality&rdquo
column5: dimensions of competencies and low in &ldquo

column1: • Field studies showed that a significant proportion of supervisors had little understanding about the content of National Education Standards or how such standards could be used to benefit schools and student learning.

• Though the survey suggests that participation in INPRES training did have a positive impact on supervisor competency, more research needs to be done to determine whether training leads to improvement in education quality and student learning outcome.
• The survey also revealed that supervisors undertook minimal continued professional development (CPD) training in the three years prior to the study.

column3: s requirement for supervisor positions to be held only by teachers with civil servant status, some have suggested for supervisors to have prior school leadership experience.

column1: ACDP has also identified certain effective practices from other Asian countries that are also going through decentralization processes. Malaysia has been developing a more critical supervision system or school &ldquo
column3: that is carried out by a team inspectors located external to the school which regularly visits and inspects schools. This type of supervision system is based on the one set up by the Office for Standards in Education (OFSTED) in the late 1980s in England and Wales. The Republic of Korea also uses &ldquo
column4: external&rdquo
column5: evaluators from the provincial and metropolitan offices of education who are located outside of the school to administer school evaluations. While Malaysia&rsquo
column6: s system covers the whole operation of the school, Korea&rsquo
column7: s uses appointed evaluation committees that do not follow uniform criteria. Both systems send the results of evaluations to the government, and, in the case of Korea, use results to financially reward well-performing schools.

column1: In contrast, countries like Kenya, Bangladesh and Nigeria have placed more focus on the supervisor&rsquo
column2: s role in supporting and developing teachers instead of their role in inspecting and critically evaluating. These countries have adopted the premise that &ldquo
column3: control without support will not lead to quality improvement&rdquo
column4: . Bangladesh and Kenya expect supervisors to have many roles such as that of head teachers
column9: a key organizer of school functioning
column10: and as administrator and academic planner.

column1: Many countries such as the Philippines, Chile and Australia are attempting to develop a system of supervision that is both critical and supportive. For example, each school in Victoria, Australia, annually prepares a self-assessment report by collecting, analyzing and reporting certain data. During this process, school principals work closely with teachers to improve the teaching learning process. Critical inspection occurs every three years by external firms that evaluate the school&rsquo
column2: s performance, report to the government and send recommendations to schools.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499140654692"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499140654692"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: Sebagai pengganti persyaratan Peraturan Menteri 21/2010 untuk posisi pengawas yang akan diselenggarakan hanya oleh guru dengan status pegawai negeri sipil, ada beberapa yang menyarankan agar atasan memiliki pengalaman kepemimpinan di sekolah sebelumnya.

ACDP juga telah mengidentifikasi beberapa praktik efektif dari negara-negara Asia lainnya yang juga melalui proses desentralisasi. Malaysia telah mengembangkan sistem pengawasan yang lebih kritis atau "
column3: sekolah yang dilakukan oleh inspektur tim yang berada di luar sekolah yang secara teratur mengunjungi dan memeriksa sekolah. Jenis sistem pengawasan ini didasarkan pada yang ditetapkan oleh Office for Standards in Education (OFSTED) pada akhir 1980an di Inggris dan Wales. Republik Korea juga menggunakan evaluator &quot
column4: eksternal&quot
column5: dari dinas pendidikan provinsi dan metropolitan yang berada di luar sekolah untuk mengelola evaluasi sekolah. Sementara sistem Malaysia mencakup keseluruhan operasi sekolah, komite evaluasi yang ditunjuk oleh Korea menggunakan kriteria yang tidak sesuai. Kedua sistem mengirimkan hasil evaluasi kepada pemerintah, dan, dalam kasus Korea, menggunakan hasil untuk memberi penghargaan finansial kepada sekolah berkinerja baik.

column1: Sebaliknya, negara-negara seperti Kenya, Bangladesh dan Nigeria telah lebih fokus pada peran pengawas dalam mendukung dan mengembangkan guru, bukan peran mereka dalam memeriksa dan mengevaluasi secara kritis. Negara-negara ini telah mengadopsi premis bahwa "
column2: kontrol tanpa dukungan tidak akan mengarah pada peningkatan kualitas&quot
column3: . Bangladesh dan Kenya mengharapkan pengawas memiliki banyak peran seperti kepala sekolah
column4: Guru kelas
column9: Dan sebagai administrator dan perencana akademis.

column1: Banyak negara seperti Filipina, Cile dan Australia mencoba mengembangkan sistem pengawasan yang sangat penting dan mendukung. Misalnya, setiap sekolah di Victoria, Australia, setiap tahun menyiapkan laporan penilaian mandiri dengan mengumpulkan, menganalisis dan melaporkan data tertentu. Selama proses ini, kepala sekolah bekerja sama dengan guru untuk memperbaiki proses belajar mengajar. Pemeriksaan kritis terjadi setiap tiga tahun oleh perusahaan eksternal yang mengevaluasi kinerja sekolah, melapor kepada pemerintah dan mengirimkan rekomendasi ke sekolah.
