column1:
18,"1","Continuous Professional Development","

Indonesia is currently reforming its national education system, presenting the opportunity to promote the development of 21st century skills to compete with other countries (particularly in the ASEAN region). In order to effectively teach those skills, teachers must be equipped with a rich repertoire/plan in learning strategies, an indepth understanding on how learning is delivered, an ability to work collaboratively, strong technology skills, and the ability to use technology as tools to enhance learning. A framework and mechanism are needed to facilitate the continuous teacher development (CPD). Law 14/2005 on Teachers and Lecturers and Ministerial Regulation 16/2007 have required teachers to possess academic qualifications and to master competency standards. Indonesia presently has 33 quality assurance agencies and 12 national centers for subject training, which are responsible for the inservice training for teachers.

Teacher Working Groups (Primary School Teacher Cluster or Kelompok Kerja Guru/KKG) and Secondary School Subject Teacher Cluster or Musyawarah Guru Mata Pelajaran/MGMP) has been recognized as the most appropriate and effective path which most teachers can take in receiving CPD. It provides a forum for teachers to discuss and work together in developing curriculum, lesson plans, teaching practice and other issues including teaching students with special needs or teaching students using their mother tongue.
An alternative form that has a similar strategy to
column3: id=82"" target=""_blank"">KKGs and MGMPs is called the &ldquo
column4: Smart Teacher&rdquo
column5: online platform (Guru Pintar Online/GPO) which is managed by Indonesia&rsquo
column6: s Open University (Universitas Terbuka/UT). GPO is an online forum or media, which opens the opportunities for teachers to help one another by sharing best practices and materials beyond their local teacher working groups. There are also platforms provided by The Center of Information and Communication Technology in Education and Culture (Pusat Teknologi Informasi dan Komunikasi Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan) under MoEC, which include online, television and radio, where teachers can draw learning and teaching materials. One of the platforms is called the Rumah Belajar, which allows teachers to create and share their teaching materials with others and it is also linked to the online portal of CPD.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499150133464"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499150133464"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

• CPD in Indonesia still requires significant improvement. A review by OECD reveals that many teachers do not receive any CPD and, moreover, receive little professional guidance by external facilitators, principals, supervisors, or even mentoring by experienced teachers.

<li>In Indonesia the current teaching working groups are yet to be considered as providing the expected results because KKGs and MGMPs still have many issues and problems. A study by the World Bank found that there are only a small percentage of teachers that have developed their skills through teacher working groups, for example: (i) knowledge and skills of teaching practice (50% teachers in KKG and 45% teachers in MGMP)
column2: and (ii) knowledge and skills of Classroom Action Research (33% teachers in KKG and 32% teachers in MGMP).

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499150133460"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499150133460"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: • The critical weakness can be addressed by providing CPD programs related to the teacher qualification process.
<li>Teacher working groups such as KKGs/MGMPs would provide better outcomes if they: (i) help teachers focus on providing more effective learning for students
column2: (ii) use evidencebased reviews from research and data on student learning outcomes
column3: (iii) support teachers to review and adapt their teaching practice according to its impact on student learning
column4: (iv) are clearly linked with school improvement, planning and management initiatives
column5: (v) restructure the curriculum of the of the CPD given in these groups by strengthening the focus on Lesson Study and building coherence around Classroom Action Research (CAR), and (vi) support them through strong leadership of school principals and by skilled external facilitators. Skilled facilitators (guru pemandu) who could be trained and experienced school principals could support local KKG and MGMP by revitalizing inactive clusters or encourage establishment of new clusters in other areas.

column1: • BERMUTU, a program which also aims to improve the curriculum used in teacher working groups. The program recommended the use of a more coherent program based on the principles of Lesson Study, which is a variant of the Classroom Action Research approach and is being adopted extensively internationally.

• USAID PRIORITAS, a USAID program which focuses on increasing access to quality basic education since 2012, facilitates training and counseling for teachers and school principals by using KKGs and MGMPs, increasing stakeholder awareness of the benefits of KKGs and MGMPS, encouraging the local government to create new MGMPs to serve all districts, trains facilitators to use Lesson Study in KKGs and MGMPs. Facilitators were also trained to plan interesting activities for teachers and to use the results of teacher selfassessment in teacher working groups. The program also ensures all teachers within each school understand and hopefully will be able to implement the methods of Lesson Study.

,Pengembangan Keprofesian Berkelanjutan","

Indonesia saat ini sedang mereformasi sistem pendidikan nasional, menyajikan kesempatan untuk pengembangan keterampilan abad ke-21 untuk bersaing dengan negara-negara lain (khususnya di kawasan ASEAN). Agar efektif mengajarkan keterampilan tersebut, guru harus dilengkapi dengan perbendaharaan/rencana dalam strategi pembelajaran, pemahaman mendalam tentang penyampaian pembelajaran, kemampuan bekerja sama, keterampilan teknologi yang kuat, dan kemampuan menggunakan teknologi sebagai alat untuk meningkatkan pembelajaran.

column4: sans-serif&quot
column5: >Kelompok guru Kerja (Kelompok Kerja Guru / KKG untuk tingkat SD) dan Musyawarah Guru Mata Pelajaran / MGMP untuk sekolah menengah telah diakui sebagai cara paling tepat dan efektif bagi guru untuk menerima PKB. PKB menjadi forum bagi guru untuk berdiskusi dan bekerja sama dalam mengembangkan kurikulum, rencana pelajaran, praktek mengajar dan isu-isu lainnya termasuk mengajar siswa berkebutuhan khusus atau mengajar siswa menggunakan bahasa ibu. Bentuk alternatif strategi yang sama untuk KKG dan MGMP disebut &ldquo
column7: online/GPO) yang dikelola oleh Universitas Terbuka / UT). GPO adalah sebuah forum atau media online, yang membuka peluang bagi guru untuk membantu satu sama lain dengan cara berbagi praktik terbaik dan bahan dengan kelompok guru di luar daerah mereka.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499150241577"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499150241577"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

• PKB di Indonesia masih membutuhkan perbaikan yang signifikan. Hasil review OECD mengungkapkan bahwa banyak guru tidak mengikuti PKB dan, bahkan, sedikit mendapatkan bimbingan profesional dari fasilitator eksternal, kepala sekolah, pengawas, atau bahkan pendampingan dari guru yang berpengalaman,

<li>di Indonesia saat ini kelompok kerja pengajaran belum dianggap memberikan hasil sesuai harapan karena KKG dan MGMP masih memiliki banyak masalah. Sebuah studi oleh Bank Dunia menemukan bahwa hanya ada sebagian kecil guru yang mengembangkan keterampilan mereka melalui kelompok kerja guru, misalnya: (i) pengetahuan dan keterampilan praktek mengajar (50% guru di KKG dan 45% guru di MGMP )
column2: dan (ii) pengetahuan dan keterampilan Penelitian Tindakan Kelas (33% guru di KKG dan 32% guru di MGMP).

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499150256366"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499150256366"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: • Kelemahan ini dapat diatasi dengan memberikan program PKB yang terkait dengan proses kualifikasi guru.

<li>Kelompok kerja guru seperti KKG / MGMP akan memberikan hasil yang lebih baik jika: (i) membantu guru fokus pada penyediaan pembelajaran yang lebih efektif bagi siswa, (1) membantu guru fokus pada penyediaan pembelajaran yang lebih efektif bagi siswa
column2: (ii) menggunakan bukti penelitian dan data tentang hasil belajar siswa
column3: (iii) membantu guru meninjau dan menyesuaikan praktek mengajar mereka sesuai dengan dampaknya pada belajar
column4: (iv) terkait dengan inisiatif perbaikan, perencanaan dan manajemen sekolah yang jelas
column5: (v) menyusun kembali kurikulum PKB dalam kelompok-kelompok tersebut dengan memperkuat fokus pada Lesson Study dan koherensi sekitar Penelitian Tindakan Kelas (CAR), dan (vi) membantunya melalui kepemimpinan dari kepala sekolah yang kuat dan oleh fasilitator eksternal terampil. Fasilitator terampil (guru Pemandu) - kepala sekolah terlatih dan berpengalaman - dapat mendukung KKG dan MGMP setempat dengan merevitalisasi kelompok kerja yang tidak aktif atau mendorong pembentukan kelompok kerja baru di daerah lain.

column1: • BERMUTU, sebuah program yang juga bertujuan untuk meningkatkan kurikulum yang digunakan dalam kelompok kerja guru. Program ini merekomendasikan penggunaan program yang lebih koheren didasarkan pada prinsip-prinsip Lesson Study, yang merupakan varian dari pendekatan Penelitian Tindakan Kelas dan sedang diadopsi secara luas secara internasional.

• USAID PRIORITAS, program USAID yang fokus untuk meningkatan akses pada pendidikan dasar berkualitas sejak 2012, memfasilitasi pelatihan dan konseling bagi guru dan kepala sekolah melalui KKG dan MGMP, meningkatkan kesadaran pemangku kepentingan tentang manfaat KKG dan MGMPS, mendorong pemerintah daerah untuk membuat MGMP baru untuk melayani seluruh kabupaten, melatih fasilitator menggunakan Lesson Study di KKG dan MGMP. Fasilitator juga dilatih untuk merencanakan kegiatan menarik bagi guru dan menggunakan hasil penilaian guru - dalam kelompok kerja guru. Program ini juga memastikan semua guru dalam masing-masing sekolah memahami dan diharapkan dapat menerapkan metode Lesson Study.

column4: font-size:11pt"">There are two different forms of absence:

font-size:11pt"">Teacher absence from school: defined as the number of teachers who were not at school (for whatever reason). This is expressed as a proportion of all teachers who were scheduled to be teaching

font-size:11pt"">Teacher absence from class: defined as the number of teachers who, although present at school, were not in the classroom. This is expressed as a proportion of all teachers who were scheduled to be teaching.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149944566"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149944566"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Substantial body of research has found that teachers are one of the most important in-school factors in improving student learning. To have a quality teaching, teachers must first and foremost be present in the classroom. High rates of teacher absence would affect the students, other teachers and operations of schools, as described in the following non-extensive list:
In unattended classes students were considerably more likely to be left without a prescribed activity.
The student absence rate was higher in schools with a high teacher absence rate.
There was some evidence that higher rates of teacher absence in primary schools were associated with lower student achievement in mathematics.
Around two-thirds of classes without their regularly scheduled teacher had a substitute. Most substitutes were assigned to more than one class during one lesson period.
In secondary schools, only about 40% of substitutes were teachers of the same subject matter as the regularly scheduled teacher.

Of classes that were in session during the unannounced visits, 9% were unattended for the duration of the class and a further 5% of classes were temporarily unattended, with the teacher later returning to class.

When unattended classes are taken into account, primary schools are estimated to provide an average of only 19 hours teaching per week and secondary schools only 23 hours per week. These are significantly below the

Teacher absenteeism rate in Indonesia has decreased from 19% in 2003 to 10% in 2013 and the estimate of teacher absence from school in 2013 is generally lower than the estimates of absence rates in few other developing countries. However, the 10% rate of teacher absence is still considered high, and the teacher absence rate from class is higher than the teacher absence rate from school.

Among different regions, types of teachers and types of schools, teacher absence rates vary widely. This suggests that policies which seek to change the conditions of schools may be effective in reducing absenteeism. Teacher absence rates were found to be generally higher:
Among teachers who worked at more than one school
In schools that had not achieved the particular
In schools where the school leader was not present or did not provide a positive role model for teachers
In schools where there had not been a recent visit from the district education office
In schools where the school committee had little engagement

The most common reason for absence was due to attending official teaching-related duties, largely due to attending meetings and trainings. There were also significant regional differences as to the reasons teachers are absent. Furthermore, most frequently, regardless of whether or not they were scheduled to teach, teachers - who were at school but not teaching &ndash
column2: were doing neither academic nor administrative activities. Only one in four teachers who were absent from class were found engaged in another academic activity, such as designing teaching materials or assessing students&rsquo

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149944562"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149944562"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: At the national level, policy priorities include:
Reconsidering the current national policies on teachers&rsquo
column2: working hours, so as to reduce the incentive for teachers to work at more than one school.

column1: Expanding the current standards concerning the expectations of teachers to include their non-teaching time and responsibilities. There is a need for the non-class teaching role of teachers to be clarified and for the environment of schools to better encourage and support teachers to use their time outside of class in ways that are more rewarding for students.

Continuing to address the broader issues of the distribution of teachers in the system. Teacher absence from school was not found to be caused by teacher shortages. Instead, as this and other studies have concluded, it is one of the symptoms of a broader challenge of the inequitable distribution of teachers in the Indonesian education system.
At the district level, policy priorities include:
Strengthening support and supervision of the teaching and learning process. Regular and focused visits by district-level officials help reinforce the importance of teachers&rsquo
column2: work, and indicate an efficiently operating district in which a range of actions that directly and indirectly encourage teacher attendance are underway.

column1: Increasing the focus on supporting schools in recording and tracking absence levels. A fingerprinting machine is only one way to do this, and the introduction of such machines without broader changes at the district level is unlikely to achieve the desired result.
At the school level, policy priorities include:
Strengthening principal selection and competency development as a key to promoting a &ldquo
Providing schools with clear policies and support for managing teacher absences and substitute teachers in ways that minimize the impact on students.
Providing schools with more support to improve the management of school schedules and teachers&rsquo
column2: roles to make the most of teachers&rsquo

column1: Building more constructive engagement by schools with their local communities.
• Wherever possible holding meetings and training days outside of regular school teaching hours.

,Ketidakhadiran Guru","

Ada dua bentuk ketidakhadiran yang berbeda:
<li>Guru bolos dari sekolah: adalah sejumlah guru yang tidak di sekolah (karena berbagai alasan). Hal ini dinyatakan sebagai proporsi semua guru yang dijadwalkan akan mengajar

column4: sans-serif&quot
column5: >Guru absen dari kelas: adalah sejumlah guru yang, meskipun hadir di sekolah, tapi tidak di dalam kelas. Hal ini dinyatakan sebagai proporsi semua guru yang dijadwalkan akan mengajar.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149961789"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149961789"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Banyak penelitian menemukan bahwa guru merupakan salah satu faktor paling penting dalam sekolah untuk meningkatkan pembelajaran siswa. Untuk memiliki kualitas pengajaran, guru pertama dan utama harus hadir di kelas. Tingginya tingkat ketidakhadiran guru akan mempengaruhi siswa, guru lain dan operasi sekolah, seperti yang dijelaskan dalam daftar non-ekstensif berikut:
• Di kelas tanpa pengawasan baiasanya dibiarkan tanpa tugas.
• Tingkat siswa yng tidak hadir di sekolah lebih tinggi daripada tingkat ketidakhadiran guru.
• Bukti menunjukan tingkat ketidakhadiran guru lebih tinggi di sekolah dasar dan mengakibatkan prestasi siswa yang rendah dalam matematika.
• Sekitar dua pertiga kelas tanpa guru yang seharusnya mengajar memiliki pengganti. Kebanyakan pengganti ditugaskan lebih dari satu kelas selama satu periode pelajaran.
• Di sekolah menengah, hanya sekitar 40% dari pengganti adalah guru dari mata pelajaran yang sama dari guru yang seharusnya mengajar.
<li>Dari kelas yang dikunjungi selama kunjungan, 9% tanpa pengawasan selama kelas berlangsung dan 5%&nbsp
column2: kelas tanpa pengawasan untuk sementara waktu, diman guru kemudian kembali ke kelas.

column1: • Ketika kelas tanpa pengawasan dimasukan, rata-rata hanya 19 jam mengajar per minggu di sekolah dasar dan hanya 23 jam per minggu di sekolah menengah. Jam mengajar ini jauh di bawah persyaratan Standar Pelayanan minimum.

Tingkat ketidakhadiran guru di Indonesia mengalami penurunan dari 19% pada tahun 2003 menjadi 10% pada tahun 2013 dan pada tahun 2013 tingkat ketidakhadiran guru dari sekolah umumnya lebih rendah dibanding dengan tingkat ketidakhadiran di beberapa negara berkembang lainnya. Namun, 10% ketidakhadiran guru masih dianggap tinggi, dan tingkat ketidakhadiran guru di kelas yang lebih tinggi dari tingkat ketidakhadiran guru di sekolah.

Di berbagai daerah, jenis guru dan jenis sekolah, tingkat ketidakhadiran guru bervariasi. Hal ini menunjukkan bahwa kebijakan untuk mengubah kondisi sekolah efektif dalam mengurangi ketidakhadiran. Tingkat ketidakhadiran guru umumnya ditemukan lebih tinggi:
• Di antara guru yang bekerja di lebih dari satu sekolah
• Di sekolah dengan fasilitas fisik yang buruk
• Di sekolah yang belum mencapai Standar Pelayanan Minimum tertentu (MSS)
• Di sekolah di mana pemimpin sekolah tidak hadir atau tidak memberikan model peran positif bagi para guru
• Di sekolah yang belum menerima kunjungan dari dinas pendidikan kabupaten
• Di sekolah di mana komite sekolah tidak terlalu terlibat

Alasan paling umum ketidakhadiran ialah karena menghadiri tugas resmi terkait pengajaran, seperti menghadiri rapat dan pelatihan. Ada juga perbedaan regional yang signifikan mengapa guru tidak hadir. Selain itu, paling sering, terlepas dari apakah mereka punya jadwal mengajar atau tidak, guru - yang ada
column2: di sekolah tetapi tidak mengajar - melakukan kegiatan diluar kegiatan akademis maupun administratif. Hanya satu dari empat guru yang absen dari kelas yang ditemukan terlibat dalam kegiatan akademik lain, seperti penyusunan bahan ajar atau penilaian kinerja siswa.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499149998658"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499149998658"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: • Mempertimbangkan kembali kebijakan nasional saat ini tentang jam kerja guru, sehingga dapat mengurangi insentif bagi guru yang bekerja lebih dari satu sekolah.

• Memperluas standar mengenai keinginan guru untuk memasukkan waktu non-mengajar dan tanggung jawab mereka. Kebutuhan peran guru di luar mengajar harus diperjelas dan lingkungan sekolah harus lebih mendorong dan membantu guru menggunakan waktu mereka di luar kelas dengan cara yang lebih bermanfaat bagi siswa.

• Terus berupaya menangani permasalahan yang lebih luas tentang penyebaran guru dalam sistem. Guru tidak hadir bukan disebabkan karena kekurangan guru. Sebaliknya, karena hal ini dan lainnya penelitian telah menyimpulkan, ketidakhadiran ini merupakan gejala munculnya tantangan yang lebih luas dari sekedar penyebaran guru yang merata dalam sistem pendidikan di Indonesia.

• Penguatan dukungan dan pengawasan pada proses pengajaran dan pembelajaran. Kunjungan teratur dan khusus dari pejabat tingkat kabupaten membantu memperkuat pentingnya kinerja guru, dan menunjukkan pelaksanaan yang efisien di mana ada upaya yang secara langsung dan tidak langsung mendorong kehadiran guru.

• Meningkatkan upaya untuk membantu sekolah dengan merekam dan melacak tingkat ketidakhadiran. Mesin sidik jari merupakan salah satu cara untuk melakukannya, dan penggunaan mesin tersebut tanpa perubahan di tingkat kabupaten tidak mungkin dapat mencapai hasil yang diinginkan.
<li>penguatan pemilihan dan pengembangan kompetensi kepala sekolah sebagai kunci untuk mempromosikan &ldquo
• menyediakan kebijakan dan dukungan yang jelas untuk mengelola absensi guru dan guru pengganti agar dampak pada siswa minimal.
• Memberikan lebih banyak dukungan bagi sekolah untuk meningkatkan pengelolaan jadwal sekolah dan peran guru untuk memaksimalkan sebagian besar waktu guru.
• Membangun keterlibatan sekolah yang lebih konstruktif dengan masyarakat setempat.
• Sedapat mungkin mengadakan hari untuk pertemuan dan pelatihan di luar jam mengajar pada sekolah reguler.

20,"1","Basic Education in Indonesia","

A number of prominent topics for basic education in Indonesia are discussed below.

In 2005, the BOS scheme was introduced and it had the largest impact at school level across the country. The government also provided BOS funds for primary and junior secondary schools since August 2005. In 2010/11 it covered around 43 million students in 216,191 public and private primary also junior secondary schools and madrasah. In 2012, the government allocated Rp 23 trillion for BOS funding, by 2013 BOS will be provided to senior secondary schools. This resulted in a significant increase of access for disadvantaged families. In 2009, the gross enrollment rate (GER) at primary school level has increased to 93.8%, and at junior secondary level the GER has raised from 52% in 2006 to 59% in 2009. BOS also helped raise the grade passing rate from 50% to 55% on the same period.
The plan of BOS funds for school operational costs is the most significant policy initiative, which is valuable for schools in poorer, more remote areas that often lack of any operational budget.
column2: However, BOS has decreased community participation in education because of parents&rsquo
column3: perception that BOS covers all costs. &nbsp
column4: Also, parents are still asked to make other financial contributions for infrastructure, equipment, and extracurricular expenses.

column1: One Roof Primary and Junior Secondary Schools
A key component of of MoEC and MoRA&rsquo
column2: s strategic plan is to combine&nbsp
column3: primary and junior secondary school (one-roof). Despite the fact that this has been an important strategy for increasing equitable access, particularly in remote area, it does not guarantee the learning quality provided
column4: as teachers in many on-roof schools are primary school teachers. Some of these teachers only have a two-year primary teacher training (PGSD) degree and even lack competency in certain subjects for junior secondary schools.

column1: Since the refurbishment process has been self-managed by the schools, this program has helped to enhance school-based management, with the involvement of school committees and parents. By doing so, it has made a significant contribution to improving learning environments.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499144712468"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499144712468"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

There is an increasing number of positive trends within basic education in Indonesia, exceptionally in terms of improving access to primary and junior secondary education. Meanwhile, the gaps still persist and much remains to be done to fully achieve Renstra targets and EFA goals by 2015.

Alongside the nine-year compulsory basic education policy, Indonesia has almost achieved universal access to primary level and compelling increases in enrollments for junior secondary level. Nevertheless, this achievements veil regional and socio-economic inequality.

column2: s, the primary enrollment rate has gradually increased. Reflected in both the net enrollment rate (NER) for primary level (95.5% in 2011/12), likewise the gross enrollment rate (GER) (115.4% for the same year). Although it shows that Indonesia is on track to achieve the Renstra target of an NER of 96% for primary level by 2014, the leveling off of both NER and GER is presumably due to the difficulty in providing access for all children, particularly those in remote areas.

column1: The UNESCO 2011 Global Monitoring Report calculated Gender Parity Index (GPI) for primary school level at 0.97. This indicates that overall opportunity to obtain and complete primary education is almost equal for boys and girls at this level. However inequality still exists in some areas, especially in Eastern Indonesia.
Junior Secondary level: In 1994 the government initiated the &lsquo
column3: program which significantly increase junior secondary enrollment. Between 2000 - 2009, there was approximately a 44% increase in the number of junior secondary schools. BOS to junior secondary schools since 2005 and subsidies for poor students have also contributed to a substantial increase in enrollment rates. It can be seen in the increase in NER, from 58.6% to 77.7% (2001-2012), close to achieving the Rensta target of 76.8% by the end of 2014. The GER also reflected the improvements, which increased from 76.1% to 99.5% (2001-2012).

id=6"" target=""_blank"">Islamic schools: As madrasah mostly serves poor rural community, it considerably contributes to the education in Indonesia towards nine-year compulsory basic education. In 2010/11, there are 22,527 Madrasah Ibtidaiyah (MI) serving 3,082,226 students (10.1% of the total enrollments for primary level) throughout the country. Along with 14,022 Madrasah Tsanawiyah (MT) - the equivalent of junior secondary level -, serving 2,587,106 students. Islamic boarding school (pondok pesantren) is the primary and junior secondary equivalency packages introduced by the Islamic education sector.

column1: In terms of basic education quality in the Islamic education sub-sector, the challenges are implemented by the limited resourcing, because more than 90% of madrasah are private or community-managed. Data from Mora indicates a high number of under-qualified teachers at 62% for primary and 35% for junior secondary schools.

International comparisons: The Global Monitoring Report (UNESCO, 2012), uses the Education for All Development Index (EDI), to show that Indonesia reached 0.938. While comparing it to other countries, Indonesia is within the medium range, ranking 64th out of 120 countries. Among neighboring ASEAN countries, Indonesia ranked lower than Brunei Darussalam and Malaysia but higher than the Philippines and Cambodia.

There are still large numbers of children who do not continue their studies beyond primary level. Based on 2009/10 school year data, the transition rate from primary to junior secondary schools is 88.2%, which means half a million children did not continue their study to junior secondary level.
column2: The transition rate to senior secondary school has tended to fluctuate. It increased from 2004/05 to 2005/6, but decreased in 2006/07
column3: increased again in 2008/09, but then decreased again in 2009/10. While the reason is still unclear, there is a possibility this happened due to the fact that certain provinces failed to submit data in that year.

column1: In 2010/11, reported data shows a relatively low dropout rates at 1.5% for both primary and junior secondary level. According to data from SUSENAS (2011), children who drop out tend to come from families with lower socioeconomic status, 64.4% of children aged 7-12 years and 50% of aged 13-15 years.

There are 17 provinces (51.5%) with a net enrollment rate for primary school along with 15 provinces (45.5%) are below the average rate for junior secondary school. For primary schools, the gap between the highest rate (Bali) and the lowest rate (Papua Barat) is about 9.1%, while the gap for junior secondary schools is much greater from 93.3% in DKI Jakarta to 62.5% in Papua. Most of the provinces that disparate are located in the Eastern Indonesia. Among the main reasons for these low NER rates may be the unavailability of school facilities and high rates of teacher absenteeism.

Despite the large number of basic education teachers, there are several critical issues that remain: inadequate qualifications of the teachers, uneven distributions of teachers, and inefficient teacher-student ratios. Although in practice the educational qualification does not guarantee better learning, only about 26.8% of primary school teachers have the minimum requirement of a bachelor degree. While in junior secondary schools 76% hold a bachelor degree. Unequal distribution of teachers also leads to a quality gap between urban and rural areas. Teachers tend and prefer to be posted in urban rather than rural areas, which resulting in understaffed schools in remote areas. To address this issue, the central government has decided to distribute teachers across provinces
column2: provincial governments may distribute teachers across districts
column3: and district governments may distribute teachers within their area. In reality, this decision is administratively difficult to implement, as all civil servant teachers are district employees, recruited locally, and receive salaries paid by the district governments. It is also challenging socially and psychologically for the teachers.

column1: There are minimum service standards for basic education in order to ensure a minimum standard of quality across all schools, which requires local governments to provide appropriate number of certified teachers, learning facilities, curriculum, and systematic quality control.
column2: Schools are also required to have a minimum number of learning hours and outcome targets, textbooks and reference books for students, learning assessment, school-level curriculum development, and effective school management and community involvement.

column1: It is difficult for the government to identify and address quality-related areas in basic education because of the absence of national map that shows the extent to which these standards are being met at both district and school levels. Other than national examination results, assessment like PIRLS, PISA
column2: and TIMSS also need to be used as quality learning outcomes indicators.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499144712463"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499144712463"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: Options include, but are not limited to (sourced from OECD/ADB, 2015, see references below):
Designing a well- targeted programme to improve education access.
Conducting trial strategies in several districts to better engage parents and families in supporting the education of their children.
Surveying teaching workforce to identify training needs in relation to the new curriculum
Investing in teacher training programmes, focused on teacher accountability.
Establishing relevant training programmes readily accessible by teachers.
Conducting audit of drop out phenomena, in aggregate and on a district level, broken down by student characteristics including location, gender, ethnicity and socioeconomic status.
Requiring districts to design targeted programmes to attain minimum service standards (MSS).
Reviewing the allocation of BOS and BOSDA grants to improve their sensitivity to varying revenue capacities and greater costs of schools according to their location, size, and student mix.

column4: Overview of the Education Sector in Indonesia 2012. Jakarta: Ministry of Education and Culture.
Education in Indonesia: Rising to the Challenge. Paris: OECD Publishing.

column1:
,Pendidikan Dasar dan Menengah di Indonesia","

Sejumlah topik penting pendidikan dasar dan menengah di Indonesia dibahas di bawah ini.

Pada tahun 2005, skema BOS diperkenalkan dan memiliki dampak pada tingkat sekolah di seluruh negeri. Pemerintah juga menyediakan dana BOS untuk sekolah SD dan SMP sejak Agustus 2005. Pada tahun 2010/11 dana BOS dapat menutupi sekitar 43 juta siswa di 216.191 sekolah dasar dan juga sekolah menengah pertama dan madrasah negeri dan swasta. Pada tahun 2012, pemerintah mengalokasikan Rp 23 triliun untuk dana BOS, tahun 2013 BOS diberikan ke sekolah-sekolah menengah atas. Hal ini mengakibatkan peningkatan akses yang signifikan pada keluarga tidak mampu. Pada tahun 2009, angka partisipasi kasar (APK) di tingkat sekolah dasar telah meningkat menjadi 93,8%, dan APK pada tingkat sekolah menengah meningkat dari 52% pada tahun 2006 menjadi 59% pada tahun 2009. BOS juga membantu menaikkan tingkat kelulusan dari 50 % hingga 55% pada periode yang sama.

Rencana dana BOS untuk biaya operasional sekolah merupakan inisiatif kebijakan yang paling signifikan, bermanfaat bagi sekolah-sekolah di daerah miskin dan terpencil yang memiliki anggaran operasional yang kurang. Akan tetapi, BOS menurunkan partisipasi masyarakat dalam pendidikan karena orang tua
column2: memiliki persepsi bahwa BOS sudah menutupi semua biaya. Orang tua masih diminta untuk memberikan kontribusi keuangan lainnya untuk biaya infrastruktur, peralatan, dan ekstrakurikuler.

column1: Sekolah Dasar dan Sekolah Menengah Pertama Satu Atap

Komponen utama rencana strategis Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan dan Kementerian Agama adalah untuk menggabungkan sekolah SD dan SMP (satu - atap). Terlepas dari pentingnya strategi untuk meningkatkan akses yang merata, terutama di daerah terpencil, namun tidak ada jaminan adanya pembelajaran berkualitas karena banyak guru di sekolah satu atap adalah guru sekolah dasar. Beberapa guru tersebut hanya mengenyam Pendidikan Guru Sekolah Dasar (PGSD) dua tahun dan bahkan kurang memiliki kompetensi dalam mata pelajaran tertentu di sekolah menengah pertama.

Karena proses perbaikan telah dikelola sendiri oleh sekolah, program ini telah membantu untuk meningkatkan manajemen berbasis sekolah, dengan melibatkan komite sekolah dan orang tua. Dengan demikian, akan ada kontribusi yang signifikan untuk meningkatkan lingkungan belajar.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499144712478"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499144712478"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Ada peningkatan tren positif dalam pendidikan dasar di Indonesia, khususnya dalam peningkatan akses pendidikan dasar dan menengah pertama. Sementara itu, kesenjangan masih ada dan masih banyak yang harus dilakukan untuk sepenuhnya mencapai target Renstra dan tujuan EFA pada tahun 2015.

Seiring dengan kebijakan wajib belajar sembilan tahun, Indonesia telah hampir mewujudkan akses universal untuk tingkat SD dan kenaikan jumlah pendaftaran untuk tingkat Sekolah Menengah Pertama. Namun demikian, pencapaian ini juga memperlihatkan adanya ketimpangan regional dan sosial-ekonomi.

Tingkat dasar: Sejak tahun 1980 an, angka partisipasi sekolah dasar telah meningkat secara bertahap sebagaiman tercermin dalam angka partisipasi murni (APM) untuk tingkat dasar (95,5% di 2011/12), demikian juga angka partisipasi kasar (APK) (115,4% pada tahun yang sama). Meskipun hal ini menunjukkan bahwa Indonesia berada di jalur untuk mencapai target Renstra dari APM sebesar 96% untuk tingkat SD pada tahun 2014, penyamarataan APM dan APK dilakukan karena kesulitan dalam menyediakan akses bagi semua anak, terutama yang ada di daerah terpencil.

Laporan Monitoring Global UNESCO 2011 menghitung GPI untuk tingkat sekolah dasar di 0,97. Hal ini menunjukkan bahwa secara keseluruhan kesempatan untuk mendapatkan dan menyelesaikan pendidikan dasar hampir sama untuk anak laki-laki dan perempuan pada tingkat ini. Namun ketimpangan masih ada di beberapa daerah, terutama di Indonesia Timur.

column2: Program Wajib Belajar Sembilan Tahun yang meningkatkan partisipasi SMP secara signifikan. Antara tahun 2000 - 2009, ada sekitar peningkatan 44% jumlah sekolah menengah pertama. BOS untuk sekolah menengah pertama sejak tahun 2005 dan subsidi bagi siswa miskin juga telah memberikan kontribusi terhadap peningkatan substansial dalam tingkat pendaftaran. Hal ini dapat dilihat dalam peningkatan APM, dari 58,6% menjadi 77,7% (2001 - 2012), hampir mencapai target Renstra sebesar 76,8% pada akhir 2014. APK juga memperlihatkan perbaikan, meningkat dari 76,1% menjadi 99,5% (2001 - 2012).

column1: Sekolah Islam: Karena madrasah sebagian besar melayani masyarakat miskin di pedesaan, madrasah memberikan kontribusi terhadap wajib belajar sembilan tahun di Indonesia. Di tahun 2010/11, ada 22.527 Madrasah Ibtidaiyah (MI) yang melayani 3.082.226 siswa (10,1% dari total pendaftaran untuk tingkat dasar) di seluruh negeri. Seiring dengan 14.022 Madrasah Tsanawiyah (MT) - setara dengan tingkat SMP -, melayani 2.587.106 siswa. Pondok Pesantren adalah paket kesetaraan SD dan SMP yang diperkenalkan oleh sektor pendidikan Islam.

Dalam hal kualitas pendidikan dasar di sub-sektor pendidikan Islam, permasalahan yang dihadapi adalah terbatasnya sumber daya, karena lebih dari 90% dari madrasah dikelola swasta atau masyarakat. Data dari Kemenag menunjukkan tingginya jumlah guru yang kurang berkualitas yaitu 62% untuk tingkat dasar dan 35% untuk sekolah menengah pertama.

Perbandingan internasional: Laporan Monitoring Global (UNESCO, 2012), menggunakan Indeks Pembangunan Pendidikan untuk Semua (EDI), untuk menunjukkan pencapaian Indonesia sebesar 0,938. Bila dibandingkan dengan negara-negara lain, Indonesia berada di peringkat menengah, peringkat ke-64 dari 120 negara. Di antara negara-negara tetangga ASEAN, peringkat Indonesia lebih rendah dari Brunei Darussalam dan Malaysia tetapi lebih tinggi dari Filipina dan Kamboja.

Masih banyak anak-anak yang tidak melanjutkan studi mereka selepas tingkat dasar. Berdasarkan Data tahun ajaran 2009/10, tingkat transisi dari SD ke SMP adalah 88,2%, yang berarti setengah juta anak-anak tidak melanjutkan ke tingkat SMP. Tingkat transisi ke sekolah menengah atas cenderung turun anik. Angkanya meningkat dari tahun 2004/05 ke 2005/6, tetapi menurun pada tahun 2006/07
column2: meningkat lagi pada 2008/09, tapi kemudian menurun lagi pada 2009/10. Sementara alasannya masih belum jelas, ada kemungkinan ini terjadi provinsi tertentu tidak mengirimkan data pada tahun yang bersangkutan.

column1: Di tahun 2010/11, data menunjukkan tingkat putus sekolah relatif rendah sebesar 1,5% pad tingkat SD dan SMP. Menurut data dari SUSENAS (2011), anak-anak yang putus sekolah cenderung berasal dari keluarga dengan status sosial ekonomi rendah, sebesar 64,4% anak usia 7-12 tahun dan 50% dari usia 13-15 tahun.

Ada 17 provinsi (51,5%) dengan tingkat partisipasi murni sekolah dasar bersama dengan 15 provinsi (45,5%) berada di bawah rata-rata untuk sekolah menengah pertama. Untuk sekolah dasar, kesenjangan antara tingkat tertinggi (Bali) dan tingkat terendah (Papua Barat) adalah sekitar 9,1%, sedangkan kesenjangan bagi sekolah menengah pertama jauh lebih besar yaitu sebesar 93,3% di DKI Jakarta dan sebesar 62,5% di Papua. Sebagian besar provinsi yang berbeda terletak di Timur Indonesia. Penyebab utamanya angka APM yang
column2: rendah adalah tidak tersedianya fasilitas sekolah dan masih tingginya tingkat ketidakhadiran guru.

column1: Meskipun jumlah guru pendidikan dasar banyak, ada beberapa masalah penting yang muncul: kualifikasi guru kurang, penyebaran guru tidak merata, dan rasio guru-murid tidak efisien. Meskipun dalam prakteknya kualifikasi pendidikan tidak menjamin pembelajaran yang lebih baik, hanya sekitar 26,8% dari guru sekolah dasar memiliki persyaratan minimal gelar sarjana. Sementara di SMP 76% memegang gelar sarjana. Penyebaran guru yang tidak merata juga menyebabkan kesenjangan kualitas antara daerah perkotaan dan pedesaan. Guru cenderung dan lebih memilih untuk ditempatkan di perkotaan daripada pedesaan, sehingga sekolah-sekolah di daerah terpencil memiliki kekurangan tenaga guru. Untuk mengatasi masalah ini, pemerintah pusat memutuskan untuk mendistribusikan guru di seluruh provinsi
column2: pemerintah provinsi dapat mendistribusikan guru ke seluruh kabupaten
column3: dan pemerintah kabupaten dapat mendistribusikan guru di daerah mereka. Pada kenyataannya, keputusan ini secara administratif sulit untuk dilaksanakan, karena semua guru PNS adalah pegawai kabupaten, direkrut secara lokal, dan menerima gaji yang dibayarkan oleh pemerintah kabupaten. Secara sosial dan psikologis hal ini juga menjadi permasalahan bagi guru.

column1: Ada standar pelayanan minimum untuk pendidikan dasar untuk memastikan standar minimum kualitas di semua sekolah, sehingga pemerintah daerah harus menyediakan sejumlah guru tersertifikasi, fasilitas belajar, kurikulum, dan kendali mutu yang sistematis. Sekolah juga diminta untuk memiliki jumlah minimum jam dan target hasil, buku pelajaran dan buku referensi belajar bagi siswa, penilaian belajar, pengembangan kurikulum tingkat sekolah, dan manajemen sekolah yang efektif serta keterlibatan masyarakat.

Pemerintah mengalami kesulitan mengidentifikasi dan mengatasi permasalahan kualitas pendidikan dasar karena tidak adanya peta nasional yang menunjukkan sejauh mana standar ini terpenuhi di tingkat kabupaten dan tingkat sekolah. Selain hasil ujian nasional, penilaian seperti PIRLS, PISA, dan TIMSS juga dapt digunakan sebagai indikator hasil pembelajaran yang berkualitas.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499144712473"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499144712473"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: Pilihan mencakup, namun tidak terbatas pada (bersumber dari OECD / ADB, 2015, lihat referensi di bawah ini):
• Merancang program yang ditargetkan dengan baik untuk memperbaiki akses pendidikan.
• Melaksanakan strategi uji coba di beberapa kabupaten untuk lebih melibatkan orang tua dan keluarga dalam mendukung pendidikan anak-anak mereka.
• Mengkaji tenaga kerja mengajar untuk mengidentifikasi kebutuhan pelatihan sehubungan dengan kurikulum baru
• Berinvestasi dalam program pelatihan guru, fokus pada akuntabilitas guru.
• Membentuk program pelatihan yang relevan mudah diakses oleh guru.
• Melakukan audit fenomena putus sekolah, secara agregat dan di tingkat kabupaten, dipecah berdasarkan karakteristik siswa termasuk lokasi, jenis kelamin, etnisitas dan status sosial ekonomi.
• Membutuhkan kabupaten untuk merancang program yang ditargetkan untuk mencapai standar pelayanan minimum (SPM).

• Mengkaji alokasi dana BOS dan BOSDA untuk meningkatkan kepekaan mereka terhadap berbagai kapasitas pendapatan dan biaya sekolah yang lebih besar sesuai dengan lokasi, ukuran, dan campuran siswa mereka.

column4: Overview of the Education Sector in Indonesia 2012. Jakarta: Ministry of Education and Culture.
Education in Indonesia: Rising to the Challenge. Paris: OECD Publishing.

column1:
21,"1","Senior Secondary Education in Indonesia","

There are several senior secondary education (SSE) type of forms in Indonesia, such a formal, non-formal, and informal. Formal SSE is offered through of general senior secondary schools (SMA), vocational senior secondary schools (SMK)
column4: id=6"" target=""_blank"">Islamic senior secondary schools (Madrasah Aliyah/MA). Non-formal SSE consists of senior secondary Package C (Paket C), which is equivalent to SMA. This section concentrates mostly on SMA and MA, though reference is made to SMK with regards to

column1: SSE has expanded through private senior secondary schools that continued to dominate the sub-sector in terms of numbers of schools. For approximately 70% of senior secondary schools, privately run schools tend to have much lower enrollments than public schools.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159446149"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159446149"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Between 2000/2001 and 2011/12, the number of private and public senior secondary schools throughout Indonesia doubled from 12,415 to 26,896. Over the same period, total enrollments increased by 82% and the number of SSE teachers nearly doubled (from 342,443 to 571,591). during the same period, There have also been steady improvements in both net enrollment (NER) and gross enrollment rates (GER).
column2: GER has increased from 42.8% in 2000/2001 to 76.4% in 2011/12, and NER has increased from 35.0% to 57.7%. The current GER of 76.4% makes the government aims for universal access to SSE by 2015.

column1: Despite this expansion, the average level of educational attainment is still relatively low. The average number of years of education of an Indonesian citizen aged 19 years (the age when a person should complete senior secondary school) and older was only 7.98 in 2010, which is the equivalent of reaching the second year of junior secondary school. Ongoing efforts to increase access to SSE will contribute to increasing the average number of years of education and will better position the country to derive maximum benefit from the &lsquo
Public school system appears to be more efficient than the private school system. The student to school ratio (SSR)
column2: in the private system is 235 students per school, while at the public system is around 513 studentsper school. In terms of student to teacher ratio (STR), the public system appears to be more efficient than the private system, 14 for SMA and 13 for SMK, while the private system has an STR of only 10 and 9 for SMA and SMK, respectively (2009/10).

column1: A comparison of GER across 460 districts shows considerable variation, from as low as 22.4% to 134.3%. The 15 provinces that have a GER below that of the national level are distributed almost evenly between Java and the western regions on one hand, and the eastern regions on the other. This suggests that the regional &lsquo
column3: (i.e. between Eastern Indonesia and the rest of the country), which is usually assumed, may not be applicable in the case of SSE enrollments.

column1: The gender parity index (GPI) of SSE shows that females at general senior secondary school or SMA level increased from 1.07 to 1.14 between 2000 and 2010. However, overall figures include the GPI for vocational schools or SMK, where the ratio of females to males has actually declined over the past decade (from 0.76 to 0.71). This may be related to the fact that many of the courses offered in SMK are regarded to relate to male-dominated occupations and that SMA courses are seen as more appropriate for females.

Senior secondary education faces problems in inefficiency in respect to dropout and repetition rates, and to a low student/teacher ratio. This represents a significant waste of educational resource, where in 2010/11, 142,275 students dropped out from SMA, while 98,640 dropped out from SMK. Furthermore, a total of 27,215 students across both types of school repeated classes. From the viewpoint of student/teacher ratio, the efficiency level of senior secondary education provision is relatively low. Furthermore, efficiency declined during the last decade. Some of the factors are the fact that the smaller size and enrollments of private SSE schools will result in a lower student/ teacher ratio. In addition, the lower student/teacher ratio for SMK may be associated with the larger number of courses and programs of study offered. Overall, while SMK offers up to 96 different study programs, SMA offers only three study programs (Natural Science, Social Science, and Language).

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159446146"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159446146"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: Options include, but are not limited to (sourced from OECD/ADB, 2015, see references below):

Responsible ministries conducting training and support for schools and school supervisors to ensure that classes are timetabled well, and that all teachers are engaging in teaching during their paid contract time.
Giving greater responsibility to school principals and senior teaching staff for quality assurance and improving learning and teaching.

Finding efficiencies in the school system to free up funds for additional school resources, including using ICT to access teaching in fields that cannot be delivered on a cost-effective basis locally.
Providing teachers a quality assurance system to be tools for evidence-based self-evaluation linked to the learning outcomes of their students.
Responsible ministries surveying teaching workforce to ascertain their training needs in relation to the new curriculum.

column4: Overview of the Education Sector in Indonesia 2012. Jakarta: Ministry of Education and Culture.
Education in Indonesia: Rising to the Challenge. Paris: OECD Publishing.

column1:
,Pendidikan Menengah Atas di Indonesia","

Ada beberapa jenis pendidikan menengah atas (SMA) di Indonesia, seperti formal, non-formal, dan informal. Pendidikan menengah atas
column2: diberikan melalui sekolah umum menengah atas (SMA), sekolah menengah atas kejuruan (SMK), dan Madrasah Aliyah / MA. Pendidikan menengah atas&nbsp
column3: non formal terdiri dari Paket pendidikan menengah atas&nbsp
column4: (Paket C), yang setara dengan SMA. Paket inilebih banyak berkonsentrasi pada SMA dan MA, meskipun pedoman untuk SMK sudah dibuat&nbsp

column1: Pendidikan menengah atas telah diperluas oleh sekolah menengah swasta yang dalam hal jumlah sekolah terus mendominasi sub-sektor ini. Sekitar 70% dari sekolah menengah atas, sekolah yang dikelola swasta cenderung memiliki pendaftaran yang jauh lebih rendah dari sekolah umum.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159446173"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159446173"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Antara 2000/2001 dan 2011/12, jumlah sekolah menengah atas swasta dan negeri di seluruh Indonesia dua kali lipat dari 12.415 menjadi 26.896. Selama periode yang sama, total pendaftaran meningkat 82% dan jumlah guru SMA hampir dua kali lipat (dari 342.443 menjadi 571.591). Selama periode yang sama, terlihat adanya peningkatan stabil baik angka partisipasi murni maupun angka partisipasi kasar. APK telah meningkat dari 42,8% di tahun 2000/2001 menjadi 76,4% pada tahun 2011/12, dan APM meningkat dari 35,0% menjadi 57,7%. APK saat ini 76,4% mendorong pemerintah untuk mencapai akses universal SMA pada tahun 2015.
column4: &nbsp

column1: Meskipun adanya penambahan, tingkat rata-rata pencapaian pendidikan masih relatif rendah. Rata-rata jumlah tahun pendidikan dari warga negara Indonesia berusia 19 tahun (usia ketika seseorang harus menyelesaikan sekolah menengah atas) dan di sebelumnya hanya 7,98 pada tahun 2010, yang setara dengan menyelesaikan tahun kedua sekolah menengah pertama. Upaya-upaya untuk meningkatkan akses ke SMA memberikan kontribusi pada peningkatan rata-rata jumlah tahun pendidikan dan menempatkan posisi negara lebih baik sehingga dapat
column4: .&nbsp

column1: Sistem sekolah negeri tampaknya lebih efisien daripada sistem sekolah swasta. Rasio siswa sekolah
column3: adalah 235 siswa per sekolah, sedangkan rasio siswa guru dalam sekolah negeri sekitar 513. Untuk rasio siswa guru, sistem negeri juga tampaknya lebih efisien daripada sistem swasta, 14 untuk SMA dan 13 untuk SMK, sedangkan sistem swasta memiliki rasio siswa guru hanya masing-masing 10 untuk SMA dan 9 &nbsp
column4: untuk &nbsp

column1: Perbandingan APK di 460 kabupaten menunjukkan adanya perbedaan, dari terendah 22,4% menjadi 134,3%. Sekitar 15 provinsi dengan APK di bawah tingkat nasional merata antara Jawa dan wilayah barat di satu sisi, dan wilayah timur di sisi lain. Hal ini menunjukkan bahwa kesenjangan daerah ( yakni antara Indonesia Timur dan wilayah lainnya), yang biasanya ada, mungkin tidak ditemukan dalam pendaftaran pendidikan menengah atas ini.
column4: &nbsp

column2: kesetaraan gender (IKG) dari SMA menunjukkan bahwa perempuan di sekolah menengah atas umum atau tingkat SMA meningkat dari 1,07 menjadi 1,14 antara tahun 2000 dan 2010. Namun, angka ini adalah angka keseluruhan termasuk IKG untuk sekolah kejuruan atau SMK, di mana rasio perempuan dengan laki-laki menurun selama dekade terakhir (dari 0,76 menjadi 0,71). Hal ini mungkin disebabkan &nbsp
column3: karena banyak program studi yang ditawarkan di SMK dianggap berhubungan dengan pekerjaan yang didominasi laki-laki dan pendidikan SMA &nbsp
column4: dipandang lebih sesuai untuk perempuan. &nbsp

column1: Pendidikan menengah atas menghadapi masalah inefisiensi yang berhubungan dengan tingkat putus sekolah dan pengulangan, dan rasio siswa / guru yang rendah. Hal ini menunjukan adanya pemborosan sumber daya pendidikan, di mana di 2010/11, 142.275 siswa putus dari SMA, sementara 98.640 putus dari SMK. Selain itu, total 27.215 siswa di kedua jenis sekolah mengulang kelas. Dari sudut pandang rasio siswa / guru, tingkat efisiensi penyediaan pendidikan menengah atas relatif rendah. Selain itu, efisiensi menurun selama dekade terakhir. Beberapa faktor penyebabnya adalah fakta bahwa ukuran dan pendaftaran yang lebih kecil di sekolah SMA swasta mengakibatkan rasio siswa / guru yang lebih rendah. Selain itu, rasio siswa / guru yang lebih rendah untuk SMK berhubungan dengan banyaknya jumlah dan program studi yang ditawarkan. Secara keseluruhan, SMK menawarkan hingga 96 program studi yang berbeda, sedangkan SMA hanya menawarkan tiga program studi (Ilmu Pengetahuan Alam, Ilmu Sosial, dan Bahasa).

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159446169"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159446169"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Pilihan yang Diajukan

column1: Pilihan mencakup, namun tidak terbatas pada (bersumber dari OECD / ADB, 2015, lihat referensi di bawah ini):

• Kementerian yang bertanggung jawab melakukan pelatihan dan dukungan untuk sekolah dan pengawas sekolah untuk memastikan bahwa kelas dapat dihitung dengan baik, dan bahwa semua guru terlibat dalam pengajaran selama masa kontrak bayaran mereka.
• Memberikan tanggung jawab lebih besar kepada kepala sekolah dan staf pengajar senior untuk mendapatkan jaminan kualitas dan peningkatan pembelajaran dan pengajaran.

• Menemukan efisiensi dalam sistem sekolah untuk membebaskan dana untuk sumber daya sekolah tambahan, termasuk menggunakan TIK untuk mengakses pengajaran di bidang yang tidak dapat disampaikan secara biaya efektif secara lokal.
• Menyediakan guru sistem penjaminan mutu untuk dijadikan alat untuk evaluasi diri berbasis bukti terkait dengan hasil belajar siswa mereka.
• Kementerian yang bertanggung jawab mensurvei tenaga kerja mengajar untuk memastikan kebutuhan pelatihan mereka terkait dengan kurikulum baru.

column4: Overview of the Education Sector in Indonesia 2012. Jakarta: Ministry of Education and Culture.
Education in Indonesia: Rising to the Challenge. Paris: OECD Publishing.
Rural Areas

column1:
22,"1","Skills Development Education","

Skills development or vocational education in Indonesia is offered formally and informally at the secondary and tertiary education levels. It is offered through SMKs at the formal secondary level, Diploma I, II
column2: and III at polytechnics and/or academies at higher education level.

column1: Enrollment in vocational education has seen a significant increase of 158% between 2001 and 2010. This rapid growth is in large part a reflection of the priority of the government, which has made this sub-sector a key strategy for economic development.

Vocational education at the senior secondary and tertiary levels is mandated under all education-related laws, including Education Law 20/2003. Standards for vocational education are determined by National Standards of Education (SNP), operated under the National Education Standards Board (BSNP). Institutional accreditation has been conducted by the National Accreditation Board for Schools and Madrasahs (BAN SM), the National Accreditation Board for Higher Education (BAN PT), and the National Accreditation Board for Non-Formal Education (BAN PNF). Teacher certification falls under the supervision of the Board of Education Human Resource Development and Quality Assurance.

The main responsibility for overseeing formal vocational education at the senior secondary education (SSE) level sits with the Directorate General (DG) of SSE. The responsibility for vocational education at the tertiary level sits with the DG of Higher Education. Non-formal vocational training is the responsibility of the DG of Early Childhood Education, Non- Formal Education
column2: and Informal Education, which are within the Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC). Operational activities related to formal vocational education at the SSE level and non-formal vocational training both fall under the responsibility of district or municipality governments.

has issued detailed competency standards and curriculum guidelines for the provision of vocational education. In addition, the Ministry of Manpower and Transmigration has issued National Competency Standards for Works, which were developed in cooperation with industry stakeholders. Currently, the government is identifying feasible ways to include industry-relevant competency standards into the curricula of vocational schools. However, neither industry nor the ministries involved have reached an agreement on how these standards could be implemented at vocational school level or in terms of curriculum components, performance assessment and certification.

column1: Under the Ministry of Education decree 036/O/1997, the SMK could provide training in mechanical engineering (previously provided through technical high schools or STM), pastry making (previously provided through tourism secondary school or SMIP)
column2: and wood-craft (previously served through handicraft industry high school or SMIK). Thus, a district may have one SMK providing&nbsp
column3: three types of skills, rather than three different schools (STM, SMIP&nbsp
column4: and SMIK), each providing&nbsp
column5: only one type of skill. This potentially improves efficiency in vocational education service delivery. The reforms also made major changes to curricula in order to ensure that student training responded to local labor market needs. A so-called &lsquo
column7: curriculum was adopted, where students study more general subjects in their first year, since many of them still could not decide their specialization, and then focus more on specialized areas as they move to higher grades.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499151118133"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499151118133"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
Quality of Graduates and Opportunity to Meet Market Demand
To a considerable extent, this expansion of vocational schooling has been &lsquo
column3: driven rather than a product of preferences expressed by the private sector, notwithstanding the innovative activities of selected SMKs in building close links with business.&nbsp

column1: Due to lack of facilities/equipment, students in private vocational schools seem to have lower scores compared to public SMKs. Public vocational students have an average math score of 5.4, while private SMK students have a lower mathematics score with an average of 5.1. There is a clear need to strengthen student performance in vocational schools, especially private vocational schools.

The availability of jobs has been big a problem for SMK graduates, as it has for other young people. There is little evidence that graduates from SMK have significantly different labor market outcomes than graduates from SMA. Graduates from SMA and SMK have similar unemployment rates upon graduation. National data show that unemployment was highest for young SMA and SMK graduates among schooling groups, reaching a disturbing level of nearly 40% in 2012. The rates for females, however, were lower in SMK compared with SMA graduates.
Demand for SMA graduates is likely to grow more quickly over the next five years than for SMK graduates.

Employer Skills Surveys show that a significant share of senior secondary graduates does not meet employer expectations, and there are no differences between SMA and SMK graduates. Employees from the vocational education stream have a higher percentage of &ldquo
column4: poor&rdquo
column5: scores from employers. However, the overall quality of employees with senior secondary education is an issue for both streams.

column1: Graduates from both SMA and SMK might suffer for different reasons. While SMK provides a quick means of training mid-level skilled workers to respond to the immediate needs of the labor market, it may not provide students with the general skills that will make them employable in the future. They also may not be able to gain access to tertiary education as even the entrance exams of polytechnics tend to focus heavily on academic skills and, consequently, have favored SMA graduates rather than SMK graduates. In turn, SMA graduates who do not enter tertiary education may lack sufficient job-relevant skills.

When expanding senior secondary education, the ratio of SMA to SMK expansion that is supply driven might inefficiently allocate students across tracks. For example, the ability of students with the potential to continue to post-secondary studies might be limited if they were streamed into SMK. In turn, providing general education to students not interested in continuing studies might be a less effective option than providing them locally relevant vocational education.

There are also no significant differences between the earnings of graduates fresh from SMA or SMK, although earnings of SMK graduates depreciate much faster after 7-8 years, even though they tended to be higher among female SMK graduates who mostly studied in less technically oriented programs.

column3: id=8"" target=""_blank"">SMK Financing and Education Cost

column1: The cost of providing and attending SMK is higher than providing and attending SMA. Thus, a proactive expansion of SMK enrolment, at a greater ratio than SMA enrolment, will have big implications on the cost of expanding senior secondary education. The increased cost might only be justified if there are clear differences in the education and labor market outcomes of students in both tracks.

Household expenditure for attending both public and private SMK is higher than attending SMA. The cost of attendance is highest for private SMK, and households spend around IDR 2.7 million a year. Students in public SMA spend almost half that at IDR 1.7 million a year. Private SMK are significantly more expensive than public SMA for all income quintiles. Expanding through private provision might be more efficient, if price differences are not a reflection of quality. However, if the private schools, which are catering to poor students, are of significantly lower quality, expanding access through private providers would be problematic in the absence of strong quality assurance mechanisms for these schools.
Public SMK have better facilities than private SMKs for all types of facilities.

Various studies have identified the most important issues associated with the expansion of SMKs are associated with the training, skills and deployment of teachers, while other problems include equipment and facilities, curriculum, links with private enterprise and certification of graduates.
<li>Teachers are typically divided into three groups: normative or teachers of general subjects such as language, religion and civics
column2: adaptive or academic teachers (teachers of math, science and related subjects)
column3: and productive or vocational teachers (henceforth referred to as vocational teachers). With regards to vocational teachers, shortages were reported by school principals as the main problem faced by SMK in over 60% of cases (Provincial Education Office, PEO, survey of SMK in 2013). There seems to be a shortage in SMK teachers, especially in private SMK, as the student teacher ratio is high. However, SMKs may have excluded other members of the teaching force like the laboratory specialist, mechanics and installation supervisors, and this should be considered. On average, public SMK have 60-80 teachers, while private SMK are much smaller and have an average of about 40 teachers. Student teacher ratios in public SMK is 1:40, while in private SMK it is 1:37.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499151118129"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499151118129"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: Ensure that there are opportunities for SMK students, especially from the poorest households, to pursue further education. Create flexible pathways so that students streamed into vocational education can gain entry into tertiary education. This will include addressing issues related to the entrance exam and assessment for
column3: id=32"" target=""_blank"">tertiary education, which are currently placing SMK students at a disadvantage in gaining entry into tertiary education.

column1: Create a demand driven mix of SMA/SMK using a functioning quality assurance system and flexible arrangements for the expansion of supply under PPP as the performance of graduates from both tracks in the labor market suggests that neither track is significantly better than the other without further study.
Ensure permeability between SMA and SMK and provide opportunities for vocational graduates to continually acquire relevant skills.

Explore different methods of providing vocational education, including through a mix of academic and vocational training. Provide vocational training in both tracks of education. In addition, balance the senior secondary curriculum of both tracks to ensure a strong base of cognitive skills by improving the quality of SMA and increasing the general curriculum in SMK, especially in the early years.
Prioritize practical experience through internships or other programs over technical education in the classroom in SMK.

• Consider more effective and efficient ways of financing expansion of SMK including different modalities of public-private partnerships (PPPs) such as public finance and private provision or vice versa.

,Pendidikan Pengembangan Keterampilan","

Pendidikan dan pelatihan kejuruan diselenggarakan melalui layanan formal dan non-formal. Pendidikan kejuruan formal lebih besar dari dua sub-sektor lain dan diberikan pada tingkat menengah melalui sekolah-sekolah kejuruan menengah atas (SMK) dan tingkat pendidikan tinggi melalui Diploma I, II, III, dan IV termasuk program 3-tahun di politeknik dan akadem.

Pendaftaran di pendidikan kejuruan mengalami peningkatan signifikan dari 158% antara tahun 2001 dan 2010. Pertumbuhan yang cepat ini sebagian besar merupakan refleksi dari prioritas pemerintah, yang telah membuat sub-sektor in menjadi strategi utama dalam pembangunan ekonomi.

Pendidikan kejuruan di tingkat menengah dan tinggi diamanatkan dalam semua undang-undang yang berhubungan dengan pendidikan, termasuk UU Pendidikan 20/2003. Standar pendidikan kejuruan ditentukan oleh Standar Nasional Pendidikan (SNP), yang dilaksanakan di bawah Badan Standar Nasional Pendidikan (BSNP). akreditasi kelembagaan telah dilakukan oleh Badan Akreditasi Nasional Sekolah dan Madrasah (BAN SM), Badan Nasional Akreditasi Perguruan Tinggi (BAN PT), dan Badan Akreditasi Nasional Pendidikan Non-Formal (BAN PNF). Sertifikasi guru berada di bawah pengawasan Badan Pendidikan Pengembangan Sumber Daya Manusia dan Jaminan Mutu.

Direktorat Jenderal (Ditjen) Pendidikan Menengah Atas memiliki tanggung jawab utama untuk mengawasi pendidikan kejuruan formal di tingkat pendidikan menengah atas. Tanggung jawab untuk pendidikan kejuruan di tingkat pendidikan tinggi berada dibawah Ditjen Pendidikan Tinggi. Pelatihan kejuruan non-formal merupakan tanggung jawab Ditjen Pendidikan Anak Usia Dini, Pendidikan Non-formal, dan Pendidikan Informal, yang berada di Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan. Kegiatan operasional yang berkaitan dengan pendidikan kejuruan formal di tingkat SMA dan pelatihan kejuruan non formal keduanya berada di bawah tanggung jawab pemerintah kabupaten atau kotamadya.

Badan Nasional Standar Pendidikan (BSNP) telah mengeluarkan standar kompetensi dan pedoman kurikulum yang rinci untuk penyelenggaraan pendidikan kejuruan. Selain itu, Kementerian Tenaga Kerja dan Transmigrasi telah menerbitkan Standar Kompetensi Kerja Nasional, yang dikembangkan dengan para pemangku kepentingan industri. Saat ini, pemerintah sedang mengidentifikasi cara-cara yang tepat untuk memasukan standar kompetensi industri yang relevan ke dalam kurikulum sekolah kejuruan. Namun, baik industri maupun kementerian terkait tidak mencapai kesepakatan tentang bagaimana standar tersebut dapat dilaksanakan di tingkat sekolah kejuruan atau dalam hal komponen kurikulum, penilaian kinerja dan sertifikasi.

Sistem baru yang dikenalkan dalam Keputusan Menteri Pendidikan no. 36 / O / 1997 hanya memiliki satu jenis sekolah menengah kejuruan (SMK) dari enam jenis yang sebelumnya ada. Dalam sistem ini, sebuah SMK dapat memberikan berbagai mata pelajaran kejuruan dan tidak mengkhususkan diri hanya dalam bidang terbatas. Reformasi juga membuat perubahan besar dalam kurikulum guna memastikan bahwa pelatihan siswa merespon kebutuhan pasar tenaga kerja lokal. Kurikulum yang disebut '
column2: broad based diadopsi untuk siswa yang belum siap untuk memilih bidang spesialisasi sehingga mereka akan mempelajari mata pelajaran yang lebih umum di tahun pertama dan kemudian lebih fokus pada bidang-bidang khusus ketika naik ke kelas yang lebih tinggi.

column3: driven dan bukan hasil preferensi yang disampaikan oleh sektor swasta, meskipun kegiatan inovatif yang dipilih SMK sangat berhubungan dengan bisnis.

column1: • Karena kurangnya fasilitas / peralatan, siswa di sekolah kejuruan swasta memiliki nilai lebih rendah dibandingkan dengan SMK negeri. Siswa SMK negeri memiliki skor matematika rata-rata 5,4, sedangkan siswa SMK swasta memiliki skor matematika yang lebih rendah dengan rata-rata 5,1. Ada kebutuhan yang jelas untuk memperkuat kinerja siswa di sekolah-sekolah kejuruan, terutama swasta.

• Ketersediaan pekerjaan menjadi masalah bagi lulusan SMK, sebagaimana dihadapi oleh anank-anak muda lainnya. Ada sedikit bukti bahwa lulusan SMK memiliki pasar tenaga kerja lebih besar dibanding dari lulusan SMA. Lulusan SMA dan SMK memiliki tingkat pengangguran yang sama setelah lulus. Data nasional menunjukkan bahwa pengangguran lebih tinggi di SMA daripada SMK, mencapai tingkat mengkhawatirkan hampir 40% pada tahun 2012. Akan tetapi Perempuan lebih rendah di SMK dibandingkan dengan SMA
• Permintaan untuk lulusan SMA cenderung tumbuh lebih cepat selama lima tahun ke depan daripada untuk lulusan SMK graduates

<li>Survei Keterampilan para pengusaha menunjukkan bahwa banyak lulusan SMA yang tidak memenuhi harapan pengusaha, dan tidak ada perbedaan antara lulusan SMA dan SMK. Karyawan dari pendidikan kejuruan memiliki persentase nilai &ldquo

column1: <li>Lulusan dari SMA dan SMK mungkin memiliki alasan yang berbeda. SMK menyediakan cara cepat melatih pekerja terampil tingkat menengah untuk menanggapi kebutuhan mendesak pasar tenaga kerja, tapi tidak memberikan rampilan umum yang akan membuat mereka dipekerjakan di masa depan. Mereka juga mungkin tidak memperoleh akses ke pendidikan tinggi karena ujian masuk politeknik cenderung lebih mengutamakan keterampilan akademik dan, akibatnya, PT lebih &nbsp

column2: efisien. Misalnya, kemampuan siswa yang berpotensi untuk melanjutkan sekolah terbatas jika mereka sekolah di SMK. Sebaliknya, memberikan pendidikan umum untuk siswa yang tidak tertarik untuk melanjutkan studi mungkin menjadi pilihan yang kurang efektif dibanding&nbsp

Biaya meningkat mungkin dapat dimaklumi bila ada perbedaan yang jelas dalam hasil pendidikan dan pasar tenaga kerja siswa di kedua tracks.

column1: • pengeluaran keluarga untuk sekolah di SMK baik negeri maupun swasta lebih tinggi dari pada sekolah di SMA. Biaya sekolah tertinggi untuk SMK swasta, dan keluarga menghabiskan sekitar Rp 2,7 juta setahun. Siswa di SMA negeri menghabiskan hampir setengahnya yaitu sebesar Rp 1,7 juta per tahun. SMK Swasta secara signifikan lebih mahal daripada SMA umum untuk semua kuintil pendapatan. Memperluas penyelenggaraan melalui jalur swasta bisa lebih efisien, jika harga tidak menunjukan kualitas. Namun, jika sekolah swasta, yang menampung siswa miskin, memiliki kualitas lebih rendah, memperluas akses melalui penyedia swasta akan bermasalah karena tidak adanya mekanisme jaminan kualitas yang kuat untuk sekolah-sekolah ini.
<li>SMK negeri memiliki fasilitas yang lebih baik dari SMK swasta untuk semua jenis fasilitas.&nbsp
<li>Berbagai penelitian mengidentifikasi masalah paling penting yang terkait dengan perluasan SMK yaitu pelatihan, keterampilan dan penyebaran guru, sedangkan masalah lain termasuk peralatan, &nbsp

Rata-rata, SMK negeri memiliki 60-80 guru, sedangkan SMK swasta jauh lebih sedikit dan memiliki rata-rata sekitar 40 guru. Rasio siswa-guru di SMK negeri adalah 01:40, sedangkan di SMK swasta 01:37.
