column2: s aim in terms of international standard schools (ISS) is to form the education standard that includes international standard units. It is a strategy for improving quality. The ISS law has been in debate and is currently under review by the Constitutional Court.

column1: ISS qualification requires a school to meet the eight National Education Standards (NES). The ISS general characteristics or requirements that are identified by Ministerial Regulation 78/2009 are: (i) using English as the medium of instruction in science, mathematics, and vocational subjects
column2: (ii) adopting curricula and an accreditation standard from an OECD or other developed country
column3: (iii) being accredited by a school in an OECD or other developed country
column4: engaging and collaborating with an overseas &ldquo
column9: id=7"" target=""_blank"">requiring teachers and principals to have S2 (masters) degrees

column2: perceptions and understanding in response to the government&rsquo
column3: s purpose in requiring ISS to be formed in every district and city. The purposes are to give parents an easy access to prepare their children to study in foreign universities after high school, to prepare students in getting employed overseas, as well as to improve the overall quality of schools in Indonesia.

column2: selected and approved schools as candidates to become fully compliant ISS called International School Stubs&nbsp
column3: or RSBI. Schools with RSBI receive additional funds to support their efforts towards ISS and an exemption from the &ldquo
column4: free education&rdquo
column5: policy (Ministerial decree 29/2007), which allows RSBI schools to collect funds from parents (tuition) to support international standard programs and resource needs. There are different management and organizational practices at the provincial and district government levels, which can be grouped into two:

column1: Organizational structures that have dedicated units and staff for managing and administering RSBI
Organizational structures that assign RSBI responsibilities to existing units and staff as additional responsibilities.
Schools selected to develop ISS schools are those among the best existing schools.
Most of the schools are located in more affluent area in district or city, and so the parents are willing to pay for extra fees

Provinces and city/districts monitor the use of funds received by RSBI. Provincial governments monitor the use of funds they distribute to schools from their own annual budgets (APBD/Province) as well as monitor block grants for RSBI received from MoEC--not all provinces receive blocks grants in a given year City/ district governments monitor funds allocated to RSBI schools from their own annual budgets (APBD/City/District) and also monitor the use of funds that the schools receive directly from MoEC.

Very few, in fact, are meeting standards. Requirement to teach English becomes a barrier for teachers and students to understand the material

column1: However, the ISS program policy and implementation environment aims to raise the education standard in a select set of schools by applying specific quality improvement measures and providing line-item resources. By carefully evaluating the ISS program, policy makers and education stakeholders are able to determine what is needed for sustained quality improvement in the Indonesian education development context, what quality improvement measures work in the Indonesian context, and what are the costs of quality improvement in terms of financial and human resources.

The vast amount of investment has not shown improvement in student performance such as the National Test (Ujian Nasional or UN) of RSBI students are on average similar to those who have not received RSBI investments. Also that the expensive equipment procured are not being used effectively.

column1: The RSBI program has also been criticized that it discriminates against disadvantaged children and children from lower socioeconomic strata. Children from lower socioeconomic groups tend to have lower academic performance than those who are from higher socioeconomic groups.
column2: Many times, the more affluent students mock the disadvantaged students who receive subsidies and special treatment.

column1: The evidence demonstrates that there is high motivation for teachers to improve instruction, learn English and work toward advanced degrees. Other schools have been motivated to improve their quality of instruction with the hopes that these schools may someday enter the RSBI program.

Termination of the program could have a negative impact in community coherence and education quality improvement motivation in the future. It will also be a waste in investments already made if the policy is terminated.
Policy Option 3 - Modify Current Policies and Regulations

The evaluation results and the ISS current research identify that shortcomings can be resolved by making modifications in the regulations underlying but not changing Law 20/2003. The advantages of this option are as follows:
Sustain and make further use of the investments already made through the RSBI program,
Not result in disappointment and reduced motivation that termination might cause at the grassroots and continue to be a motivating factor to improve quality both in RSBI and neighboring schools,
Continue to serve as an entry point for international best practices without the difficult-to-achieve requirements that ISS adapt foreign curricula and receive foreign accreditation,
Only require further modest investments by government by leveraging contributions from affluent parents and the business community,
Impose sanctions to ensure at least 20% of students come from poor households and that these students are supported in RSBI.

This option requires significant changes in Ministerial Regulation 78/2009, but not in the Law, such as removing the requirement to teach in English. The evaluation indicates that by removing contextually-related ISS compliance barriers, RSBI have can serve as the entry point and center for dissemination of much needed international best practices.

Initiation of an inter-directorate ISS Task Force to facilitate and oversee the consultations and drafting of the new ministerial policy regulation for ISS is also suggested. Another suggestion is to modify Ministerial Regulation 78/2009 as follows:
Remove OECD or other developed country accreditation.
Remove OECD or other developed country curriculum adoption
Include OECD or other country curriculum as reference curriculum
Add graduation requirement by adopting an international exam innovation
It is also recommended to limit the fees charged in order to &ldquo
column3: and give more opportunities to the less affluent to enroll their children in RSBI. Provincial governments should be encouraged to support RSBI with their decentralization budgets. The lack of opportunities for disadvantaged children and children from lower socioeconomic strata is the major issues that needs to be addressed. The subsidies should be enough to cover all student needs including books, uniforms, and extra-curricular activities. Disadvantaged students encounter financial, academic&nbsp
column4: and cultural barriers to participate in RSBI. &nbsp
column5: These students should receive special remedial instruction in order to enable them to compete in RSBI schools.

Tujuan UU No. 20/2003 adalah untuk membentuk standar pendidikan yang meliputi satuan bersandar internasional sebagai strategi untuk meningkatkan kualitas. UU mengenai Sekolah Berstandar Internasional

column1: Namun, kebijakan dan implementasi Program SBI bertujuan untuk meningkatkan standar pendidikan di sekolah tertentu dengan menerapkan langkah-langkah peningkatan kualitas dan menyediakan sumber daya terkait. Dengan melakukan evaluasi pada program SBI, pembuat kebijakan dan pemangku kepentingan pendidikan dapat menentukan apa yang dibutuhkan untuk peningkatan kualitas berkelanjutan dalam konteks pembangunan pendidikan di Indonesia, apa langkah-langkah pengembangan kualitas yang
column2: berjalan dalam konteks Indonesia, dan apa biaya peningkatan kualitas dari sisi keuangan dan sumber daya manusia.

column1: Investasi yang besar untuk program RSBI adalah untuk membangun infrastruktur, pengadaan peralatan dan melatih para guru dengan dana pemerintah yang signifikan (lebih Rp.1 triliun), serta jumlah biaya yang dibayarkan oleh orang tua dan sumbangan dari masyarakat dunia usaha. Siswa, personil sekolah, orang tua dan masyarakat berharap sekolah internasional tersedia di setiap kabupaten dan kota di negara ini. Biaya dan persepsi bahwa program ini adalah program pemerintah bersubsidi untuk &ldquo

column1: Pilihan kebijakan ini menyimpulkan bahwa standar untuk memilih sekolah yang memenuhi standar internasional belum efektif dalam meningkatkan pretasi siswa pada ujian nasional Indonesia. Sulit, mahal dan memakan waktu untuk memenuhi semua standar dan persyaratan untuk RSBI.

Tingginya biaya program dalam menyerap dana pemerintah dapat digunakan untuk kebutuhan yang lebih penting seperti membantu sekolah dan kabupaten dalam memenuhi SPM dan melaksanakan pendidikan dasar gratis sesuai dengan kebijakan saat ini. Investasi yang besar belum menunjukkan peningkatan prestasi siswa seperti dalam Ujian Nasional dimana hasil UN siswa RSBI rata-rata sama dengan mereka yang tidak menerima investasi untuk
column3: peralatan mahal yang dibeli tidak digunakan secara efektif.

column1: Program RSBI juga dikritik sudah mendiskriminasikan anak yang kurang beruntung dan anak-anak dari strata sosial ekonomi rendah. Anak-anak dari kelompok sosial ekonomi rendah cenderung memiliki prestasi akademik yang lebih rendah daripada mereka yang berasal dari kelompok sosial ekonomi yang lebih tinggi. Seringkali, siswa yang
column2: lebih makmur mengejek siswa yang kurang beruntung yang menerima subsidi dan perlakuan khusus.

column1: Bukti menunjukkan adanya motivasi guru yang tinggi untuk meningkatkan pengajaran, belajar bahasa Inggris dan bekerja untuk maju. Sekolah lain telah termotivasi untuk meningkatkan kualitas pengajaran dengan harapan bahwa sekolah-sekolah ini mungkin suatu hari nanti masuk dalam program RSBI.
Penghentian program bisa berdampak negatif pada koherensi masyarakat dan motivasi peningkatan kualitas pendidikan di masa depan. Hal ini juga menimbulkan pemborosan
Pilihan kebijakan 3 - Memodifikasi Kebijakan dan Peraturan yang berlaku

Hasil evaluasi dan penelitian SBI saat ini mengidentifikasi bahwa kekurangan dapat diselesaikan dengan memodifikasi peraturan yang mendasari tanpa mengubah UU nomor 20/2003. Keuntungan dari pilihan ini adalah sebagai berikut:
• Mempertahankan dan memanfaatkan investasi yang diberikan melalui program RSBI,

• Tidak mengakibatkan kekecewaan dan berkurangnya motivasi karena penghentian mungkin berakibat di tingkat akar rumput dan terus menjadi faktor pendorong dalam meningkatkan kualitas di RSBI dan sekolah tetangga,
<li>Terus berperan sebagai titik awal praktik terbaik internasional tanpa kesulitan untuk mencapai persyaratan SBI mengadaptasi kurikulum asing dan menerima akreditasi asing, &nbsp
• memerlukan investasi yang tidak besar dari pemerintah karena memanfaatkan kontribusi dari orang tua dan dari masyarakat bisnis,
• Menjatuhkan sanksi agar setidaknya 20% dari siswa berasal dari rumah tangga miskin dan bahwa siswa tersebut dibantu di RSBI.

Pilihan ini membutuhkan perubahan signifikan dalam Peraturan Menteri 78/2009, tetapi tidak dalam UU, seperti menghapus persyaratan untuk mengajar dalam bahasa Inggris. Evaluasi menunjukkan bahwa dengan menghapus hambatan kontekstual terkait SBI, RSBI dapat berfungsi sebagai entry point dan pusat penyebaran praktik terbaik internasional.

Inisiasi gugus tugas SBI antar-direktorat untuk memfasilitasi dan mengawasi pembicaraan dan penyusunan peraturan kebijakan menteri baru tentang SBI juga disarankan. Saran lain adalah untuk memodifikasi Peraturan Menteri (Permen Diknas) Nomor 78/2009 sebagai berikut:
• Hapus OECD atau akreditasi negara maju lainnya.
• Hapus OECD atau adopsi kurikulum negara maju lainnya
• Sertakan OECD atau kurikulum negara lain sebagai kurikulum acuan
• Menambahkan syarat kelulusan dengan mengadopsi sebuah inovasi ujian internasional

Hal ini juga dilakukan untuk membatasi biaya yang dikenakan dan memberikan lebih banyak kesempatan kepada yang kurang makmur untuk mendaftarkan anak Pemerintah provinsi harus didorong untuk mendukung RSBI dengan anggaran desentralisasi mereka. Kurangnya kesempatan untuk anak-anak yang kurang beruntung dan anak-anak dari strata sosial ekonomi rendah merupakan masalah utama yang perlu ditangani. Subsidi harus cukup untuk menutupi semua kebutuhan siswa termasuk buku, seragam, dan kegiatan ekstra kurikuler. Siswa yang kurang beruntung menghadapi hambatan keuangan, akademik, dan budaya untuk berpartisipasi dalam RSBI. Siswa-siswa ini harus menerima pengajaran remedial agar
Untuk memvalidasi keberadaan RSBI, standar akreditasi baru harus sesuai dengan orientasi / fokus internasional yang menetapkan kinerja yang lebih tinggi dari Standar Nasional akreditasi &ldquo
column3: . Manajer dan pelaksana program di sekolah kabupaten dan provinsi harus sepenuhnya memahami peraturan baru dan memiliki keterampilan yang dibutuhkan untuk memantau dan mengevaluasi kemajuan dalam memenuhi standar akreditasi baru dan untuk mengakses prestasi yang dibuat oleh RSBI.

column1: Untuk meningkatkan kualitas, guru dan kepala sekolah harus berusaha untuk memfasilitasi dan mengelola peningkatan praktek mengajar seperti mengadopsi dan melatih metode baru, menemukan cara untuk mengintegrasikan siswa pada TIK, merumuskan rencana pengembangan profesi guru berdasarkan kolaborasi dengan rekan-rekan, refleksi diri dan evaluasi, dan menemukan cara untuk menumbuhkan komitmen secara teratur dan konsisten berbagi pengetahuan dan pengalaman praktis dengan rekan-rekan untuk perbaikan kualitas secara keseluruhan yang meliputi inklusi dan dukungan dari semua siswa, tidak peduli keadaan keuangan atau latar belakang sosial mereka. Kepala sekolah harus mengetahui dan menerapkan metode kepemimpinan yang meliputi tujuan jangka panjang pengembangan pribadi/profesional dan mengembangkan kinerja staf sekolah.

24,"1","Gender Mainstreaming","

Indonesia has been improving gender equity in education since the last decade. The country does so
column2: by taking further steps to provide equal access for both genders by committing to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The MDGs and SDGs have included gender equity in both primary and secondary education, as well as in early childhood, technical and vocational, and higher education. Gender parity at all levels of the education system and literacy rates for Indonesia&rsquo
column3: s youth (15-24 age group) have been greatly achieved. These achievements came from the combination of effective policies and national investments in education that have expanded school availability in rural areas the lowered the school costs.

column1:
,Pengarusutamaan Gender","

Indonesia telah meningkatkan kesetaraan gender dalam pendidikan sejak dekade terakhir dengan mengambil langkah-langkah lebih lanjut untuk memberikan akses yang sama pada kedua gender. Negara ini berkomitmen untuk Millenium Development Goals (MDGs) dan Tujuan Pembangunan Berkelanjutan (SDGs). MDG dan SDG mamasukan kesetaraan gender dalam pendidikan dasar dan menengah, serta pendidikan anak usia dini, teknis dan kejuruan, dan pendidikan tinggi. Kesetaraan gender di semua tingkat sistem pendidikan dan tingkat literasi untuk pemuda Indonesia
column3: kebijakan yang efektif dan investasi nasional pendidikan telah memperluas ketersediaan sekolah dengan biaya yang kecil di daerah pedesaan.

25,"1","Student Health and Nutrition","

The Supplemental Food for School Children Program (PMT-AS) was launched to contribute to acceleration of achievement of national development goals related to: overcoming malnutrition (the incidence of stunting in children aged 6-14 years was 13.3 percent for boys and 10.9 percent for girls in 2010, according to Riskesdas)
column2: achieving education for all (primary school dropout rates in some provinces exceeded 3 percent, according to Kemendiknas in 2009)
column3: and poverty reduction (30 million Indonesians were below the national poverty line, according to Susenas in 2010).

column1: The PMT-AS Program was formulated to: (1) improve nutritional intake
column3: (3) increase the attendance and learning interest
column4: (4) increase preference for local nutritious food
column5: (5) improve hygiene and healthy behaviors including healthy eating habits
column8: s income through the increased use of local products.

column1: During 2010 and 2011, the program was implemented by the Ministry of Education and Culture (MoEC) and the Ministry of Religious Affairs (MoRA). In 2010 the target was limited to regular and madrasah primary schoolchildren (SD/MI) grades 1-6, and in 2011 preschoolers (TK/RA) were added to the program. In 2011 the program was implemented in 27 districts in 27 provinces covering 1.2 million TK/SD children and 180,000 RA/MI children. The funding allocation for snack supplements for regular schools (TK/SD) for the western region was Rp 2,500 per serving and Rp 2,650 per serving for the eastern region. The unit cost for madrasah (RA/MI) was Rp 2,250 for the western region and Rp 2,600 for the eastern region. The total PMT-AS budget for 2011 was about Rp 300 billion (USD 34 million). The target scheduling for both years was 108 child feeding days (CFD). The program was intended to provide 15% of the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) of calories (300 calories) and 10 percent of the RDA of protein (5 grams) through supplemental snacks prepared by local school personnel and community members.
The priority criteria for selecting districts in each province were: i) the less developed, remote, and island areas
column2: ii) districts with a high percentage of poor people
column3: and iii) districts with a high percentage of stunted children. Presidential Instruction 1/1997
column4: was the legal basis of PMT-AS.

column1: The evaluation of the effectiveness and impact of the PMT-AS Program was made by assessing the program&rsquo
column2: s success in meeting the 16 indicators established for the evaluation. Program effectiveness was measured through assessment of indicators grouped under inputs, process and outputs. Program impact was assessed through a set of impact indicators that measure the extent to which the program has improved students&rsquo
column3: overall health and nutrition, their knowledge, attitudes and behaviors relating to healthy living and the extent to which these conditions affect student academic performance and school attendance as well as the program&rsquo
column4: s effects on the community as a whole.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1497998830886"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1497998830886"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp

Although PMT-AS Program was only implemented for two years (2010 and 2011), there is sufficient evidence that the program does have great potential value. However, failure to adhere to feeding schedules in practice resulted in under achievement of program objectives. The analysis strongly indicates that the program has not been fully implemented as intended primarily because delays in funds reaching the target location, i.e. the schools, and that in many cases the total funds reaching the school were not sufficient to provide supplements in accordance with the intended feeding schedule. and in the intended quantities because targets were set before the academic year began and the exact number of students enrolled was not yet known.

Funding allocations also did not take into account variability in costs and availability of locally procured products and ingredients. The evidence also indicates a lack of full understanding of nutrition on the part of program implementers in the schools which can be attributed in large part to inadequate training. Inadequate training also does not prepare the program implementers and managers to consider correct alternatives if the program&rsquo
column2: s technical guidelines cannot be followed for various local reasons. The unavailability of funds specifically designated for management resulted in lack of coordination, monitoring, reporting. All these factors contribute to the lack of impact expected on improved nutrition.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1497998830881"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1497998830881"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Proposed Options

column1: The evaluation revealed a 35 percent deficit in consumption of calories in the 4 -12 age group in the schools surveyed (average 1,100 calories vs. RDA 1,750 calories) and a deficit of 20 percent in consumption of protein (32.3 g vs. RDA 39 grams). Therefore, the PMT-AS Program should be continued to provide assistance to make up the nutritional deficit of students. PMT-AS should be considered a strategic investment in developing Indonesian human resources. The following are nine recommendations to improve the effectiveness of the PMT-AS Program in the future:
Increase the amount of calories and protein to close the nutrition deficit gap
Determine the most effective and efficient distribution of supplements
Determine unit cost and frequency of supplements required to provide RDA calories and protein
Produce legal regulation and alternative funding mechanism

Streamline institutional arrangements , with MoEC as the lead sector at the center and District Education Offices (Dinas Pendidikan) at the provincial and district levels as lead sector in the regions. The coordination between key stakeholders such as MoRA, MoH and MoHA at all levels needs to be strengthened and their functions and roles should be more clearly specified
Strengthen integration of health, nutrition and healthy lifestyle in the curriculum
Revise selection criteria, define it by sub-districts with household poverty rates at 10 percent or more
Improve training, guidelines and instruction manuals and strengthen MONEV
Place more emphasis of importance of water and sanitation in PMT-AS program.

column4: Evaluation of the Supplemental Food for School Children Program: Executive Summar. Jakarta: ACDP.

column2: s two-part (MoEC and MoRA) funding passage makes basic education financing here rather complicated. <a href=""/topic.php?lang=1&amp
column4: id=1"" target=""_blank"">Basic education is mostly provided by the national education budget. 66% from MoEC, 28% MoRA, and the remaining 6% distributed to other ministries providing training and education. 60% of the national budget is transferred to sub-national governments by MoEC, while MoRA manages its fund allocation straight to schools. Another significant allocation is the school operational assistance grant (bantuan operasional sekolah/BOS), which is allocated to schools via the provincial offices. The BOS programme aimed to help the financial burden on families of sending their kids to school. Unfortunately, among its issues is the fact that although the grant is meant for development costs of a child, schools tend to use it to manage operational issues.

column2: s database have been made by giving unique numbers to individual students and identifiers for schools with their GPS coordinates to make an effective system for expenditure tracking. However, there are some issues with the efficient use of resources, such as the difficulty to know how money is being spent and identify where it goes. Planning and budget are more focused on the needs of the organizational units within the bureaucracy than the schools themselves
column4: per-student formula does not take into account the differences in operating costs schools face due to the circumstances of, among others, their populations and locations.

column1: There are also some issues in equity, such as the fact that funding for private madrasah is unequal compared to funding for state schools, including state madrasah. Also, to enable greater allocative and technical efficiencies, the education financing still needs to be integrated and simplified. Equity concerns are being addressed by BOS and to a lesser extent the BSM.
Education financing encompasses very much every aspect of education. This section is therefore divided according to issues identified in ACDP&rsquo

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751721"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751721"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: BOS - Issues

column1: Bantuan Operasional Sekolah (BOS), or School Operational Fund was introduced in 2005 as a program through which the Government of Indonesia, having legislated compulsory basic education, offered support to schools and madrasahs offering basic education programs. The program'
column2: s specific focus has been on funds for schools&#39
column4: operational non-personnel budgets. The program&#39
column5: s introduction in 2005 was a result of the government&#39
column6: s decision not to increase the country&#39
column7: s fuel subsidy, but to direct the money saved in this way to programs which were more likely to help poorer sections of the community.

column1: BOS fits into the broad structure of education funding in Indonesia, which consists of the following elements:
personnel funding to pay for salaries of teachers and school/madrasah support staff
minor investment funds for items such as school books, teaching aids and some equipment such as computers or generators
funds for major repairs of facilities and equipment
operational non-personnel funds for goods and services needed by schools/madrasahs to deliver the educational program, including maintenance of facilities and equipment.

For 2005 and 2006, there was a joint system for administration of the BOS program for both schools and madrasahs, but since 2007 this has been divided, with schools and madrasahs having separate administration systems. In all the years during which BOS funding has been provided, the payments have been made on the basis of student enrolment numbers.
Among issues associated with BOS, was the fact that an examination of the 13 components permitted to be funded shows that they are not always defined in a way which reflects BOS'
column2: s objective of raising the quality of education. They merely describe some areas of activities and types of expenditure for which the funds can be used. Where the concern for quality is seen more clearly is in forms BOS-K1, and BOS-K7 used by schools/madrasahs to report planning and implementation based on their own annual programs. These documents demonstrate how the results of self-evaluation are translated into plans and actions designed to bridge the gap between the current position of the educational institutions and the quality standard as defined by either MSS or NES. This documentation format also allows the recording of judgement as to how effectively the program to bridge the gap is being implemented. The gap analysis itself and school and madrasah targets to bridge the gap are not required by BOS Juknis.

column1: Using this format of planning and reporting means that schools/madrasahs still have the additional, previously-existing requirement of reporting their expenditure by the 13 cost components of BOS - such as honorariums, consumables and services - but this reporting can be done in a simple format. Since its primary purpose is informing key local stakeholders, it can be done in a format suitable for display on a notice-board. Schools/madrasahs may also choose to display a report on expenditure in this simplified format, though they are not required to do so.

It should be noted that the cost components of BOS funding, as listed, are not of a uniform kind. Some are types of activities, while other are payments for types of goods or services. The activities which are specified do not cover all the activities which could need to be undertaken to achieve either MSS or NES. They also do not cover all possible activities which are to be found in school/madrasah planning and budgeting documents. This adds considerable complexity to the required bookkeeping, accounting and reporting at school/madrasah level, effectively establishing two accountability systems which are at least partially disconnected.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751719"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751719"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: BOS - Proposed Options

column1: Several alternatives are available for overcoming the difficulties associated with planning and reporting processes and formats.

Planning for and reporting on each standard to include itemisation of activities. It should be noted that this is already the requirement, but indications are that the instructions are often not complied with by most schools/madrasahs.

Planning for and reporting on each standard but without itemisation of activities. Although this approach has not previously been used in school/madrasah long-term and annual planning documents, it should not cause difficulties for principals, being a relatively simple exercise. It is less complex than alternative 1, above.

By the 13 components of BOS: (a) Separately from plans to achieve required quality standard, either MSS or NES. No budgeting per activity. Previously done without difficulties, but the cost components should be revised to exclude all &ldquo
column4: (b) Planning for each standard to include itemisation of activities and cost components, budgeting of and reporting on cost components (type of expenditures)
column5: (c) Separate from planning for achievement of standard. Includes activities but not budgets. The budget can be presented separately, arranged by type of expenditure or by BOS cost component. Previously done without difficulties.
column6: (d) The BOS components are included as part of the plan for achievement of standard. This has not been done previously in this integrated way, and would present some difficulties.

column1: It would appear that the best option may be one similar to option 3.c, if a free simple software (for example ACDP 006 Template) is provided to schools and madrasahs with access to electricity and computers. Otherwise option 2 would be the best. It would involve the production of two separate planning and reporting instruments, but it would help to provide a comprehensive planning process for the schools/madrasahs, as well as providing the system with information which it does not currently have.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751716"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751716"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: BSM - Issues and Proposed Options

column1: The impact of BSM is least at the elementary level. Expect for cases in poor remote areas and in some urban areas, children will go to SD/MI with or without BSM. National participation rate is about 95%. Causes of poor elementary attendance may be due in part to non-financial factors, such as the case in Papua where the school has not been operating for three months although some students received BSM.

The data indicate that about 72% of the very poor (as defined by the survey) received BSM while only about 50% of the near poor (again as defined by the survey) received BSM. A great deal of resentment was expressed especially by those who do not receive BSM although they are of the same poverty levels as those who do. A very small portion of BSM is awarded to the middle-upper financial classes. Although the number is small, people know this. Thus, many survey respondents question the accuracy and transparency of the program.

Students do not know whether or not they will receive BSM until they have enrolled in school. This has an impact especially on transitioning students. For example, a student from a very poor family who has graduated from elementary school may not even register for junior secondary because the costs are prohibitive. However, if the student knew in grade 6 that he/she would receive BSM in junior secondary there is a greater likelihood that the student would make the transition. This appears to be the reasoning for the present TNP2K policy to provide BSM to students in class 1 and class 7 in order to encourage transition. (However, as discussed below this message must be much better socialized.)

column2: s study stated that BSM amounts should be increased, but there is a wide variation in the amounts suggested. The policy issue to be considered is the extent to which BSM is to cover the expenses for schooling. The current BSM amounts which were increased significantly beginning in 2013 show that BSM covers about 69%-72% of state basic education costs and 56%-64% for state madrasah, while BSM covers about 46%-66% for private general schools and 74%-100% for private madrasah. The analysis of the survey data suggests that current BSM funds could be increased for the very poor, especially those 5% of elementary and 22% of junior secondary aged students not currently enrolled in school.

column1: At the basic elementary level, the targeting of BSM appears to be more pressing than the amounts, especially for private madrasah. However, although specific quantitative data was not available for senior secondary, the qualitative data indicated that expenses are very high and the BSM at Rp1,200,000/year is not sufficient to cover the costs of fees and other expenses. This is a serious concern considering that that are about 240,000 senior secondary dropouts per year
column2: and because the enrollment numbers are small, the teacher student ratio is very low which makes the system inefficient.
One size does not fit all.&rdquo
column3: There is a wide variation in the cost of living and hence the cost of schooling across the country as indicated by various data sets produced by Badan Pusat Statistik (BPS)). Several respondents mentioned that the amount of BSM should be adjusted to the cost of living in each region. It would seem that this would be more effective and more cost efficient than provide the same amount everywhere.

column1: Late BSM funds distribution has a negative impact on the program because students need money at the beginning of the school year to buy uniforms, supplies, pay for transport and in some cases pay fees and tuition They also need disbursements at the beginning of the second semester to refresh supplies and pay fees where required. (Many respondents favor two disbursements per year vs. one payment.) Cases are reported of students being criticized or ridiculed because they have not paid their fees because the BSM was late in coming. Cases were reported of BSM distributions being made in the month of May for the school year that began in July the previous year.

The greatest portion of BSM funds is used for buying uniforms, especially at the elementary and junior secondary level (fees are the biggest expense at senior secondary). Cases was found in a number of sample districts where students are required to buy up to five sets of uniforms for elementary school and six sets for secondary.

The survey data indicate that dropout rates are manageable over the past three years in which the BSM program has been operating, with the exception of Papua region where the dropout rates remain much higher compared with the rest of the country. While the vast majority of principals and teachers believe BSM has reduced dropout rates and improved attendance, less than 50% of parents and students confirm this. At the time of the survey, only small portions of the new increased BSM amounts were disbursed
column2: thus, it was too soon to determine if the new BSM rates will improve parents&rsquo
column4: attitudes toward dropout and attendance.

column1: There were almost universal complaints about BSM disbursement procedures. The current practice of disbursement through banks is problematic especially for those who live far from the disbursing bank. The administrative requirements are difficult for some to follow
column2: sometimes several trips have to be made in order to produce the proper paperwork
column3: students often need to make an initial deposits in order to open an account which is a burden on poor families
column4: travel to and from the bank is expensive in terms of money and time (in a case in Papua the trip to and from the bank had to be made by boat which took three days to make the trip) and especially for elementary school students someone from the school needs to accompany them.

column1: The 2013-2014 BSM Guidelines (Juknis) issued jointly by the Directorate Generals of Basic and Senior Secondary Education clearly state that students&rsquo
column2: BSM funds should not be cut by anyone. However, many cases of this happening were reported in the survey. The Guidelines also state that the principal can collect the funds on behalf of the students if it is too difficult for the students to travel to the disbursing agency. However, there is no mention in the Guidelines how the transportation costs for collecting the funds are to be covered. In some remote places the transportation costs are substantial. Most district government officials (Dinas Pendidikan) and principals strongly recommended management and administration funds be allocated to cover such expenses.

column1: Socialization of the BSM and KPS programs is severely lacking. Several survey respondents, especially parents and village heads, did not understand that KPS could be used to apply for BSM. A number of school principals were unclear about some of the regulations. For example the principal of a vocational school specializing in agribusiness was unaware that the Directorate of Vocational Education issued guidelines that all students in agribusiness vocational schools are eligible for BSM because he had not received the guidelines at the time of the survey in mid-October 2013. Essentially no respondents knew about MOEC&rsquo
column2: s complain BSM center or how to lodge complaints.

column1: KPS and BSM cards which were derived from the TNP2K national database were the main criteria for nominating BSM beneficiaries. However, the survey could determine that only about 51% of the BSM beneficiaries used these documents to apply for BSM. Nearly 50% used poverty certificates (SKTM) issued by the village government or were classified as fatherless children or orphans or other factors applied such as political pressures. The survey could not determine whether or not those who used SKTM were included in the TNP2K national database but did not receive KPS.
The transparency and accountability in issuing the SKTM were questioned. Some cases were reported where the village authorities issued SKTM to anyone who asked, whether they are poor or not
column2: and in some cases fees were charged for issuing SKTM. Thus, school authorities are suspicious of the motives of the village heads, and at the same time the village heads stated they are the ones who know who is poor and not and so should be involved in the BSM targeting. Suggestions were made to form a task force comprised of village and school officials and school committee members to validate the poverty status of those targeted for BSM.

column1: Several cases of political intervention were reported. Politicians said that they were given a certain number of BSM to distribute. There are cases where the students were only given one-half of the amounts they deserved.
Improving the provision of scholarships for the poor in the future

A greater role for the province should be considered. Provincial authorities consulted in the survey said they are left out of the process but are willing to help if regulations are drafted to define their role in the BSM program. For example, one district in the Kalimantan region could not fulfill its BSM quota. If the province was given a coordination role, the province could redistribute quotas according to supply and demand. The province could also help to monitor targeting, validating poverty data, and program implementation.
MORA has a mechanism that appears to be complex. BSM for state schools is included in the routine budget (under &ldquo
column3: ), while BSM for private madrasah appear under a separate budget category (&ldquo
column4: Bantuan&rdquo
column5: ). Recommendations were made that MORA and MOEC use the same mechanism for targeting, budgeting and programing BSM.

column1: The Papua-West Papua region has needs that are different and greater than the rest of the country. Data indicate for example that dropout rates are greater in Papua compared with other regions. The lack of infrastructure and poor teacher management in addition to overall under socio-economic development especially in the rural regions, require special attention and special BSM policies.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751712"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751712"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Findings on Parental Contributions

column1: The Survey of Parent Contributions to Basic Education was required as a deliverable of ACDP'
column4: Free Basic Education Strategy&quot
column5: . Its draft methodology and instruments were approved as a part of the project&#39
column6: s Inception Report. The sample size of the survey, as proposed in the Inception Report, was to include 4,032 parents from 336 schools/madrasahs in 14 districts/cities. Budgetary constraints resulted in the sample having to be reduced to 2,781 parents in 228 schools/madrasahs in 10 districts/cities.

column1: The study was carried out to establish the education-related costs borne by parents of children in basic education. In addition, data gathered from the schools/madrasahs in the sample included information about their total budgets and total contributions received from parents during the 2010/2011 school year, as well as information about how these funds were used.

By utilising data from the Education and Social Module of the National Economic and Social Survey (Susenas), the study was also able to analyse the trends in parental contributions over time, and the effect of the provision of School Operational Funding (BOS) on parents&rsquo
column2: expenditure in educating their children. The Education and Social Module is administered every three years, with the most recent one administered in 2009. Data for years 2003, 2006, and 2009 were analysed to determine overall trends in parents&rsquo
column3: contributions over time including an analysis of the change in subsets of the expenses such as fees, uniforms, snacks and transport.

column1: The survey found, among others, that parents in all types of schools/madrasahs made substantial contributions to the cost of providing basic education to their children (Tables 5 and 6, below). Costs of junior secondary students were generally higher than those of primary students, except for students in private MTs'
column2: s, who tend to come from the lowest socio-economic strata of Indonesian society. The highest categories of cost incurred by all parents were pocket money, student transport and uniforms. School fees were a major expenditure item in secondary schools/madrasahs, with those in private SMPs being the highest, followed by government MTs. The cost of pocket money may appear high, but it is common in Indonesia for parents to give children money to buy a &quot
column4: on a school day. There is no mandated number of days on which Indonesian children have to attend school, but given an average of around 200 effective school days in a year, the average value of pocket money given to a student on a school day ranges from approximately Rp 4,900 in government MTs to Rp 2,200 in private MIs.

column1: Another finding was the fact that willingness of parents to make contributions was highest among schools/madrasahs with highest level of national accreditation (A), and lowest among those with lowest accreditation (C), probably indicating that the perceived quality of a school/madrasah has an impact in this regard. Parents from all schools/madrasahs indicated that among budget items to which they were prepared to contribute, teacher wages and incentives rated very highly. The only items rated more highly were laboratories for SMPs. These also rated highly among parents of MTs'
column2: s, both private and government. Student excursions and books for libraries generally rated lowest.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751710"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751710"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Senior Secondary Education Financing - Issues and Proposed Options

column1: The current funding of government senior secondary education is complex and varies throughout the country. It involves different levels of government providing financial support for infrastructure, salaries and operational costs. A common feature of the senior secondary sub-sector is its dependence on parental contributions. This has implications for school quality and for equity. The government&rsquo
column2: s policy of designating some schools as &lsquo
column4: (RSBI) has inadvertently adversely affected equity.

column1: The ACDP study found considerable variation in the levels of cost and the amounts of available revenue among state senior secondary schools (SMA), with the RSBI being far better resourced than the rest. Salaries of government service teachers (PNS) are the responsibility of government. Those of teachers without PNS status, who are numerous in some schools, have to be paid for from other sources and almost invariably these costs fall on parents. The burden on parents comes in various forms. There are direct charges for fees and registration books and uniforms and there are indirect costs of transport and meals. There are also high opportunity costs of sending children to senior secondary school to set against the perceived returns of this level of schooling.

In seeking a more rational funding arrangement for senior secondary education, a number of important policy issues were raised. These concern the relative responsibilities of different levels of government for senior secondary education and the nature and magnitude of parental contributions. These issues need to be addressed in the knowledge that Government finances are limited and that decisions need to be made on the &ldquo
column3: level of user charges, because the private returns to this level of education are high. Such decisions will have implications for social policy and the government&rsquo
column4: s stated intention of extending access to all. It also raises questions about the efficacy of efforts to reduce the cost burden for poor families through selective government subsidies and other pro-poor schemes.

column1: There are efforts at various levels of government to support an expansion of senior secondary education. The central government is supporting investment in school building and subsidising operational costs through BOMM (grant assistance for quality and management) and an extension of per-capita school grants (BOS). It also promotes participation of poor students through scholarships (BKMM). District governments have introduced schemes to provide revenue to schools and reduce the burden of school fees. Some are also increasing enrolments through innovative school structures, such as the filial schools in Grobogan and Karawang.
There are also policy options that cover, among others,
column2: the need for greater supply of places, both for the currently projected rise in the number of children graduating from junior secondary schools and for an extra 260,000 children who will need to be enrolled if the 85% target is to be reached in the next two years. Reliance on school building to meet the challenge will not be sufficient, because of the very high costs involved and the limited time available. Other approaches are examined. These include structural innovations, such as the grouping of schools to reap economies of scale and overcome geographical obstacles. The filial schools model is one such example, but there are also other models in operation in other countries. These include the use of distance learning and the application of new technology. Increased efficiency, particularly in the major cost item, the use of teachers, would be a source of major savings which would free up resources for expansion. In order to reap efficiency gains the government needs to look critically at student-teacher ratios, which are very low, and teachers&rsquo
column3: time on task. Teacher absenteeism and the practice of having several jobs mean that unit costs are much higher than they need to be.

column1: <h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751709"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751709"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Madrasah Financing - Issues

column1: The majority of the private madrasah are far behind state schools/madrasah in meeting MSS. This ACDP study provides the following preliminary estimates of costs for private madrasah to meet only certain MSS: MI require Rp 1.5 trillion for infrastructure rehabilitation, Rp 340 billion for teachers rooms and furniture, Rp 41 billion for lab equipment and books
column2: MTs require Rp 920 billion for infrastructure rehabilitation and Rp 2.3 trillion for lab equipment and books. Further, perhaps the greatest issue to address and to cost is that of private madrasah teachers. Just gathering the data upon which to calculate financial resources needed will be challenging considering that such data from MoRA to date has not been adequate for planning needs at the national level.

column1: It should be noted that some private madrasah are not operating efficiently or effectively and continued government funding to these institutions should be reconsidered. For example, a private junior secondary madrasah (MTs) in Buleleng, Bali has a total of 43 students which requires nearly Rp 300 million per year to operate at absolute minimum standards. This institution could be merged with other nearby schools
column2: it does not serve an isolated community.

column1: The main funding source for both state and private madrasah is the government with smaller contributions from the community. The proportions of government and community funding for private MI is 75:25, for private MTs 70:30, and for private MA 42:58. While this analysis demonstrates that private madrasah are very dependent on the government for funding, it does not address the issue concerning the adequacy of the funding for private madrasah nor the unequal allocation of MoRA budgets for madrasah education.

Government funding for state MI was on average five times greater than government funding for private MI. Central MoRA was the major source of government funding, while local governments made relatively minor contributions. Madrasah are by law part of the National Education System. They make a significant contribution to meeting district enrollment standards (APM/APK) and Human Development Index targets (IPM). Madrasah (MI) take about 11% of primary school enrollments and 22% of junior secondary enrollments (MTs). The vast majority of madrasah are private. While the local governments depend heavily on madrasah to help them meet enrollment standards, they are constrained from providing financial support because of prevailing laws and regulations that prohibit them from funding madrasah on a regular basis, specifically Law 32/2004 concerning local government, Government Regulation (GR) No. 38/2007 concerning division of authority among levels of government, and MoHA Regulation (Permendagri) 32/2011 concerning grants and social assistance.

Funding mechanisms especially at the local level are inconsistent. In some places because the Office of Education could not (or would not) fund private madrasah, the Peoples Welfare Office (Kesra) located in the regional Secretariat provides support in the form of Social Donations. Although there is the desire on the part of some local governments to provide more support to private madrasah, they feel constrained by current regulations, especially those under MoHA.

In conclusion, private madrasah cannot rely on community funding if they are to achieve MSS and eventually NES, and therefore the total overall performance of education is severely negatively affected since private madrasah make such a large contribution to district enrollments. Therefore, additional government funds are required to enable private madrasah improve the quality of education. The current legal framework and funding mechanisms under decentralization must be modified to allow better coordination and management of basic education at the district level.

<h4 class=""collapsible-item-title panel-title""><a aria-controls=""collapseCollapsible1499159751702"" aria-expanded=""false"" class=""collapsed collapsible-item-title-link-icon pull-right"" data-toggle=""collapse"" href=""#collapseCollapsible1499159751702"" role=""button""><span class=""glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-down"">&nbsp
column2: Madrasah Financing - Proposed Options

column1: The recommendations are made in full awareness that a tremendous amount of new additional funding will be required to enable both state and private madrasah to meet MSS and later NES. The recommendations are also made with the awareness that revisions in current regulations will be required which will involve the highest levels of government (DPR, MoHA, MoF, BAPPENAS, MoEC, MoRA and MenPAN among others) as well as public consultations. Considering the sensitivity of the issues, these debates could be contentious. Nevertheless, the issues identified in the study are pressing and at some point in time demand attention. The alternative policy instruments outlined here are based on careful analysis of a great quantity of data and stakeholder input and are meant as a contribution to the continuing dialog among the public and government in regard to improving Indonesian education, with a particular emphasis on the role of madrasah in the national education system.
Revise laws and regulations to enable local governments to contribute towards funding of madrasah, particularly private madrasah
Create a special arrangement whereby management of madrasah basic education (MI/MTs) is deconcentrated to local government
Deconcentrate madrasah education management to provincial and district MoRA offices which then contract madrasah basic education to community institutions
Improve funding equity between public and private madrasah
